This game is unplayable on modern PC's. The resolution is too small to read the words. I tried every way to fix the issue from both Steam and Paradox forums. Nothing works. I have played this game for 1000's of hours when it was a CD, long before it was on Steam. Loved the game, but it just has not aged well over the past 12 years. 
Edit: I have since had to buy a cheaper simpler computer and now I can play the game. What is broken and I never noticed it before is the war mechanic. There is a 5 year wait period before one can start the declaring war process. It is almost impossible to raise jingoism enough to add war goals, though I chose every jingoism option as they presented themselves. As the US, it took me 5 wars and 30 years to take the area that the US won in 2 years during the Mexican-American War of 1848. I conquered every inch of Spain and colonies and could do nothing more than a white peace, though Spain bizarrely declared war on me. Fortunately, there are fixes online.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Don't know why I haven't reviewed this years ago but it's probably the best PDX game to this day. 

As always, it comes with the classic Paradox game mechanics and a blatantly cheating AI that makes you want to throw your PC out of the window and makes you wonder why am I spending all these hours in the game and writing positive reviews in the first place. For example you get -1000 chances for forming alliance with a great power if you already have one great power ally. Doesn't bother the AI which happily forms alliances with 4 different GPs that will always respond to call to arms while for the player the AI breaks alliances (and game doesn't inform you anyhow about this) randomly and changes its mind constantly making any kind of long term planning impossible. 

Definitely a game I love to hate but for some reason keep coming back to. But as Paradox has displayed with HoI4, CK3 and Vic3, the new era of casual-friendly, DLC spewing, money milking, easymode not-so-grand strategy games is the future of this genre, if you do like factory building, gas attacks and rebel hunting, this is the best you're going to get.

Victoria II, a Paradox Interactive gem, delivers a deep grand strategy experience set in the 19th century. With intricate economic systems, complex diplomacy, and historical accuracy, it's a challenging yet rewarding game. While visuals may show their age, an active modding community breathes new life into this historical epic. For strategy enthusiasts, Victoria II remains a timeless journey through the complexities of the Victorian era

I'm gonna write a short review for this game because I just really like Victoria 2. This was the second ever Paradox game I ever tried out after someone recommended it to me, and I am glad they did because this game is a blast. Between changing laws, creating an empire, putting down rebellions, and building your industry, you always have something to do as long as you have a set goal in mind. 

For example, you might decide you want to play as Two Sicilies and unite the Italian Peninsular, okay well you're going to need a strong army and weapons for that army, and then create alliances and agreements with some neighbours, sphere others, and go to war with a few. Once you've done that, what next, well you could colonise Africa, well time to build docks and more armies, throw in some ships, increase your Intellectuals and increase education spending for research for better technology to colonise lands that haven't been colonised yet, or you could steal colonies from other powers, like the Ottomans, or the French. Maybe by game end you have a massive military industrial complex and a modernised Army and Navy, with ports and colonies in Africa and Asia, though not many allies in Europe from having to fight many of them.

My point is Victoria 2 on it's own is a great game, but you know what makes a game better, mods, and Vic 2 has many good mods, just go to Mod DB and go through Vic 2 mods, you want more alt his, go with Grand Combination, which is a combination of various mods like Historical Flavour and Historical Project, adding both alt history and what occurred in our time. You could also try out Divergences of Darkness, an interesting universe with a map that is completely different to our own. There are also smaller mods like Blood and Iron, which is a mod that is for balancing and adds a few features as well. Either way if you want a mod for something, it might exist on Mod DB.

TL;DR: Game has lots to do if you set goals, and mods make this already great game even better

Masterpiece of grand strategy games.

You will love this game. 
1. It has an immersive economy simulation, in which the goods become more complex. You need to produce or buy from the market manually or automatically, which in turn depends on your politics and diplomacy (including world status)
2. An fullstretched market system.
3. Great micro-management Army system, which develops through time: The more (soldier) population you have, the greater the armies. As such the army systems develops from late napoleonic to trench warfare throughout the game.
4. There is even more - I love this game.

- Dozens of mods which will add a flavour to your gameplay.
- Uniting (Super) Germany.

I must say that it is not your average strategy game, but that's what makes it special. The fact that it doesn't only focus on the war itself, but rather on all of the changes that happened bertween the 19 and 20th centuries makes it a great choice for history enthusiats. However, the fact that the war is not the main aspect doesn't mean it doesn't matter, because you can basically turn your nation into the strongest empire the world has ever seen.

It certainly takes time to learn, but is well worth the investment for those with the patience to learn it.

Would I recommend it to anyone who's not familiar with the type of game?
No, buy Victoria 3 Instead

Despite all of this, I still love this game. Once you're familiar with the mechanics, It truly feels like the sky's the limit. Want to make Romania the world's dominant power? You can. Want to completely shatter Germany, giving them no chance of recovery? You Can. Want to spread the International Proletarian Revolution from America? You 125% Can. And with mods, there are insane amounts of flavor and depth that other games (specifically Victoria 3) are just lacking. It truly makes you feel like you're [i] in [/i] the victorian era.

Plus, it tends to go on Sale for $5. If you're going to get it, get the DLCs with it, as it's basically unplayable without them.

Victoria 2 is a grand strategy game that engages you in the economic and political intricacies of the 19th century. The game's economic simulation is unparalleled even today in just about any other strategy title, with a vast array of resources and industries to manage, and a detailed population system that affects everything from your workforce to your military manpower.

The game's fitting soundtrack adds to the overall atmosphere and really helps to transport you back in time. From the orchestral music to the sound effects of factories and trains, everything feels authentic and adds to the immersion.

Although it shares elements of other military strategy games, the game's combat and army management system leave something to be desired. The combat is simplistic and lacks the depth and strategy of other games in the genre, making it feel like an afterthought rather than a core aspect of the game. An entire campaign's climax is decided by the roll of a few dice, which I suppose is fitting in a sense but is simply frustrating in practice. Additionally, army management is clunky and unintuitive, with a confusing interface that can be frustrating to navigate. The lack of any composition template system means every army has to be hand-crafted and any refitting of the armed forces is a micro-intensive practice, disincentivizing large-scale combat.

Despite these shortcomings, I still heavily recommend Vic 2 for fans of grand strategy games. Its economic simulation is top-notch, and the game offers a unique and immersive experience that is still enjoyable nearly a decade and a half later. If you can overlook the game's flaws in combat and army management, you'll find a rich and rewarding game that will keep you engaged for hours on end. Get it on a decent sale if you can.

Victoria II: 6th War of American Containment

With Vic' III on the market now, slowly falling over in the cupboard as Paradox does their standard routine of "release the framework of a game and add all the features you want in DLC updates", people are going to begin slowly trickling in to Vic II. Much is the way of vidya, when new thing come out, people go back to old thing. Except there's one thing.

The old thing has most if not all of similar problems.

Out of all of the map games, I have such a love/hate relationship with Vic' II. It is a fun game in regards to politicking, industry building and taking your average mediocre nation of choice and becoming a global powerhouse. The absolute humor of seeing things like Japanese Africa, Russian Brazil or American Africa never gets old. The issue is that the AI is absolutely, without question, the worst part of this game. It is both braindead in producing nothing, building factories everywhere and guiding their armies into weird corners of a map for no reason, while also having HoI brain where the SECOND they can declare war on you or get a casus belli, they pop it. You want to declare war on the CSA? Here comes England. You want to reclaim Liberia after a putsch? England is here to say no. If you breathe too loudly anywhere in New England, the British Empire can and will start a war with you.

Is this a skill issue? Yes. It doesn't make that infuriating and no amount of mods will undo the absolute fun that is trying to get to 1890 without someone on planet Earth starting a War of You Containment. The fact this was left in the game and no one's really questioned it in 13 years and then acted surprised Vic' III's got the same problems astounds me. It is a game that requires a lot of drilling to make functional and not an insufferable game of cat and mouse with the Austrians because god forbid I unite Germany.

The big advantage of Vic' II is being dirt cheap and having three DLC's that actually matter. So you can buy it on sale usually for five bucks, get all the DLC for an extra five bucks and have a gay old time. UNTIL THE SEVENTH WAR OF AMERICAN CONTAINMENT OVER HAWAII.

Victoria II is a game that lets you experience the history of the 19th and early 20th centuries, from the industrial revolution to the world wars. You can choose any country and guide it through political, economic, and social changes, while interacting with other nations and competing for influence and resources.

One of the my favorite feature of the game is the mod POD, which stands for Pop Demand Mod. This mod adds a lot of depth and realism to the game, by simulating the events and movements of the Victorian era not by scripted events, but by the population and an elementary economics model. This means that the game is more dynamic and unpredictable, and that you have to pay attention to the needs and desires of your people, as well as the market forces and global trends.

Victoria II is a game that requires a lot of strategy and management, but also rewards you with a rich and immersive historical simulation. It is not a game for everyone, as it can be complex and challenging, but if you are interested in the period and enjoy grand strategy games, you will find it very satisfying and fun.

[h1]VICTORIA 2[/h1]
[hr][/hr]

Where do I begin? Victoria 2 is probably the most unique of the Paradox map games. Where as most of her sibling games are more about map painting, Vic2 puts a lot of focus on the economy. It changes and fluctuates depending not only by what you do but by what the AI (more so other players in multiplayer) do as well. Annex a province? Now you have direct access to the taxes of the citizens and factories there but also have to pay the bureaucrats, clergymen, and soldiers that live there. Going to war? Those soldiers need guns and so does the enemy. Built a factory? That needs to import the resources required to output goods. 

That's not to say that Vic2 doesn't have map painting. Hell, I would say it's probably one of the most satisfying Paradox game to map paint in. You have a variety of map modes you can paint in. You can watch as the cultural demographics of your country shifts from one to another. You can watch the entirety of the Americas be blue as you enforce the Monroe Doctrine using your sphere of influence. Or you can control the geopolitical scene with your name stretching over your country, your puppets (just like CK2), and the colonies you control around the world. Though the shift from provinces to states is a letdown, as unless you're using mods, the command console, or just so happen to conquer a country that doesn't control a full state, you will be stuck with countries having their borders line up with mostly modern ones.

Warfare I would say is a mix between CK2, EU4, and HoI4 (let me explain). Like EU4, you have 3 unit types: infantry, artillery, and cavalry. Infantry and cav in the first row, artillery hopefully in the second. Combat as well comes down to modifiers such as generals and terrain being added to a random roll of a dice, as well as mil tech adding more damage or defense to units so they either kill more of the enemy and die less. Like CK2, you have a variety of different ways to fill those three unit types. 11 to be precise. Like HoI4, specifically in the later game, warfare switches from moving stacks to siege high value provinces to a more front line system. Though this is technically an artificial change, created by countries being able to fund a larger army rather than any real mechanical change.
The naval system is much the same except without the elements of HoI4 in it.



That's not to say Victoria 2 is without fault. There are quite a few problems. 

For one, it's very much a spreadsheet simulator or a mindless "number goes up = good" experience depending on how you play. The economy is pretty complex with multiple tabs just dedicated to different aspects. You can manually increase or decrease the demands for certain goods depending on what you need (I do bet some average players don't know this), create certain factories to min-max what you produce and do so in an effective manor, and focus on conquering/colonizing certain regions for raw goods. Or you could just move the sliders so that you're making money while manning a large army.

Another is the AI. No AI is perfect in Paradox titles, and are often easy to exploit. That's all well and good for most titles. However it does become a problem with Vic2. Due to how the economy works, every "civilized" nation (or westernized in mods) and "uncivs" (unwesterns) within a sphere contributes it's resources to the global pool and also takes from it to fulfill their own internal demands. And every citizen, factory, and unit has demands. The AI doesn't know how to prioritize what's demanded and properly adjust when such demand drops on a local level. This can easily lead to economic crashes, such as the American lumber industry ceasing to exist due to Russia overproducing lumber, or not having enough goods for changing after a long period of war or peace.

The biggest issue, however, has to be the unfinished nature. Without DLC, there is a lack of polish or QoL features. You are quite literally forced to play on an older version. Even with DLC most places run out of flavor and things to do early on, or its too spread out. Not to mention that 99% of the flavor is entirely historical or dynamic, with a few easter eggs and proper alt history paths. This is in spite of how diverse this period of time was, with multiple events that could have changed the course of history. On top of that, there's not a lot of historical events actually within the game, with huge events such as the '48 revolutions and many era-defining wars completely absent or improperly represented. Despite what people say, Victoria 3 does have more flavor in it's base game than Vic2 did in its last real update of 3.03.
To get the flavorful content that people love about this game you have to download mods. Yes, being dependent on mods is a downside of a game, even if said mods are really good (looking at you, Skyrim). That being said, unlike some other Paradox games mods for Vic2 tend to be good. Very few filler, one-note memes, and unbalanced messes are present with most mods focused on adding content. The modding scene is active despite the game's seemingly small community, too.



Overall, I would say [b]buy this game![/b] Especially when on-sale. Pick up both expansions as well. The upsides outweigh the downsides, and the biggest downside can be fixed with mods (despite what I said about dependent on mods).

Victoria 2 (with DLC) is the one Paradox game where it really feels like I'm leading a country rather than a blob, toon or war machine. The population has agency, what they feel and want is important and can open or close various avenues of action. When they revolt it's my own workers I'm killing, my brigades are formed from POPs in their home provinces and can run out of replacement soldiers or themselves revolt. POPs change profession, social class and location pretty much unaided, all I have are a few nudges I can deploy. It feels more like a living breathing improving world than a sandbox and that goes for the economy too. 

Every instance of a good not in existence at game start is created by a POP doing something. The market for produce in excess of consumption is anachronistic. Vic 2 scores each country on the sum of prestige, industrialisation and military points. Excess world goods are offered for sale to each country in turn, for consumption or stockpiling. None left, SOL. Try again tomorrow.

The top eight countries are Great Powers, able to influence other countries into their sphere of influence and get involved in crises. The next eight are Secondary Powers who can colonise along with the GPs. The GP system makes for crazy coalition wars and crises create a lot of opportunities for intrigue and derring-do. The Scramble for Africa is nicely done with a decent random element, also evident in the invention system. 

But most of all, Vic 2 feels like a tight, focused game that captures the romantic spirit of the times. The AI is good enough to try and accomplish various tasks, but also seems to have a keen eye for weakness in general.  The pacing is good, the player focus where it should be and the base mechanics are interlinked well enough to create plenty of interest. You really don't have to play like an expert or know how it all works to do well. Every playthrough is different (even from later stem saves) and I usually have ideas for the next game well before the finish. I haven't felt the need for mods yet.

Perhaps the best grand strategy from Paradox. Very deep and diverse — but not frivolous — game mechanics, that make a fun and sufficiently realistic victorian age imperialism simulator. Very active and prolific mod community, always keeping the game fresh and improving what is needed. Victoria 2 may be 13 years old already, but surely isn't obsolete, nor outdated. Overall it doesn't get behind the new RTS titles, including Victoria 3. The graphics and interface may be old, but it doesn't matter at all. Such elements are not essencial in this type of game (Vic2's interface does the job). Essence is what matters here, and Vic2 has planty of it — and it's a good one.
shite

This game is a micro nightmare. It is okay, but I cannot get into it in the same way as I get into other paradox products.

The biggest problem is no "batch" actions, and no automation to compensate.
let me explain.
If you want to make a factory in stellaris, you can manually click through menus, or just click an option to have AI do it for you. More importantly, it is only, like one menu to click on. A better game would have a template system, that would let you create world templates, and apply them to planets of your choice, but the AI is pretty good about choosing useful buildings.

Victoria 2 has nothing like this. it is, like three menus per factory, and you cannot stay in the menu to build the factory. you can not automate this in a practical way (capitalists will VERY slowly expand factories, but it is purely random, and not beneficial to your economy), and you cannot create regional templates to make it a one-click process. this is incredibly slow, to the point where I cannot even describe it. just, like, play china, and you will understand.

Another issue is military control. Every paradox game that I have played has bad military controls. I have heard HOI4 has a better system, but I have not tried it yet. this one is REALLY bad. Vic2 controls have a system where you select one unit, and select its location. pretty simple, right? wrong. You can have literally hundreds of armies that all need to be individually controlled. You might say that this is fine, just merge your units into a doomstack. This is even worse. This game has fast ground capturing, and a supply system. if your army is too big, it will just melt due to lack of supplies. worse, your enemies will just split up, and capture all your ground faster than you can physically, individually move every single one of your armies to stop them. I cannot describe how awful this is. imagine clicking, like 200 times, and still losing. imagine, having to pause the game every 5 minutes for 10 minutes just to be able to control it. 

The economics could be fun, but they are not the "hyper-realism" that people declare it as. 
The UI is garbage, but it is a paradox game, so it is actually mid-range.

Just, like, play factorio, mindustry, or a more enjoyable progression simulator for a more pleasant micromanaging game. They have good UIs, controls, and better mods. 

I have *200 hours in factorio, and it felt like I could play it for a hundred more without even modding it. I have 30 hours i this game, and I never want to play it again, even with mods.

Victoria II is my favorite Paradox title they've ever released. The game excels at recreating the period by adding in-depth mechanics and flavor. Building up your nation over the course of a century by managing its economy and expanding throughout the world if satisfying. Every game is different, so you as the player need to decide what you want to accomplish every game. If you want to be the world hegemon, you can do that. If you want to take your country down a different path, you can do that. The game is great at making you feel like you are building up a powerful empire. Multiplayer in this game is not fun to set up, but if you can play it I definitely recommend it. No paradox game has ever provided such a great opportunity for roleplay in multiplayer. If you are into history and enjoy the time period I cannot recommend this game enough. It is very easy to learn and get into, and it can provide you with hour-long campaigns.

A complex, wide-scope grand-strategy game set between 1836 and 1936, where you manage the economy, politics, military, research and society of a nation. Or try your best, at least, until you realize that your people are growing hungry and restless and the Jacobins call for your head.

It's always satisfying to achieve major feats. Unify Germany, become an industrial powerhouse, become the hegemon of your continent, or of the world. There is no set goals for the game but the ones you set out for yourself, although the game does prod in certain directions.

The base game is mediocre; get the expansions (A House Divided and Heart of Darkness) for a properly (almost) polished game. Maybe get some mods too; they can really enhance the game or even take it into entirely new realms.

tl;dr:

1. Get the expansions and the patches. You'll need them. I can't stress this enough.
2. The game has a strong learning curve, and some things, like the economy, you'll have to do math *and* use your gut feeling. Just like real life economics!
3. It's more fun to play a command economy, but you get more money as laissez-faire.
4. Mods make this a lot better, if you want.

❤ Audience ❤
☑ Normal Gamer [It does have a learning curve and slightly tricky gameplay]

☼ Graphics ☼
☑ Good [They do their job]

♬ Music ♬
☑ Beautiful [Nice Victorian era music, although it can get repetitive after a long while.]

☠ Difficulty ☠
☑ Average [After a few hundred hours]
☑ Hard [At first]

§ Bugs §
☑ Lots of bugs [If you push the engine, it gets buggy]
☑ Few Bugs [On normal gameplay, you may see a few minor ones]

☯ Story ☯
☑ Alright [Historical gameplay, but you can change history]

⚔ Gameplay ⚔
☑ Frustrating [At times, especially when losing]
☑ Boring [If you're not into strategy games]
☑ Fun [If you are into strategy games]
☑ Challenging [It can be really hard at times]

۞ Game time / Length ۞
☑ Few hours (10 - 20 hours) [Give or take, each individual campaign]
☑ Extremely Long (101+ hours) [Lots of replay value]

$ Price / Quality $
☑ Wait for Sale [Get base game + big DLCs]

I’m an emotionally barren neckbeard, a broken man whose only enjoyment in life comes from playing Paradox strategy games. (That’s also my Tinder bio btw.) I just sit to play a game as China in Victoria II however, and I feel my power flow.

As a true sigma male I have never once played as the French in Victoria II. I simply refuse to let those “people” become the largest super power.

Victoria II it’s actually a pretty simple game. It's just stuck behind an unintuitive UI and layered behind submenus. At its core its just an incremental simulation game with chaos sprinkled in and 1800's dressing. But by the gods does seeing those numbers move about satisfy. 

It’s amazing. But it’s f**ked. It’s too short - only 36500 ticks. It’s too buggy at times. It’s utterly a mess under the hood. But it’s amazing. Sort of like learning to play chess, but the rulebook is in Old Polish so you have to translate first.

The economic system in Victoria II it’s like trying to understand Quantum Mechanics - if you think you understand the Vic II economy, you don't understand the Vic II economy. Just like the real economy actually.

Victoria 2 is clunky and badly shows it's age.  There's lots of systems in it that are pretty bland and that are frustrating, ahistorical, and unfun.  But I still love the game and Victoria is special for a lot of reasons. 

Overall while it’s old as f*ck and a deeply flawed game, Victoria 2 is so loved because it offers a unique gameplay experience that no other game does.  One would be that it's a time period seldom covered in other games. It's also the time period that covers the greatest changes to human existence in history.

You also can't take a one-province s*ithole to a superpower status like in EU4. I'm not going to say it's realistic, but it gives a good challenge to the player.

It's a game that heavily focuses on politics, industry, economy, and the social aspects of countries while being highlighted by occasional war. The flipped version of basically every other Paradox game.

It's done so incredibly well and with such complexity that it basically outpaces every other game, even if I personally enjoy their other titles - It's just that good at its job even after all these years.

In conclusion…

…great game, great memes, great depression, great war. Alas, Victoria 3 is finally here. The missions, the nightmares… they’re finally over.

This game is genius. Also, broken - but only in small ways, that are easy enough to overlook for how much of a complex beast it is and how well it manages to function regardless.

So, what's it about? On the surface, it's a game of globe-spanning diplomacy, conquest, and social and economic development during the Victorian era. This, it manages well enough to keep someone engaged and interested for at least a few hours. Which is necessary, because the real meat-and-potatoes of the game are in its population and economic mechanics, and those take a while to learn properly. The level of detail with which production and consumption of different goods (services are either abstracted away as part of a good, or paid for by government spending) across a global market is pretty decent for a game that was ultimately built on top of a military strategy engine - each province in the game has inhabitants, which are lumped together into 'POP's; these have different jobs, different levels of education, different stressors and access to technological development, and all of these things affect what goods they want to consume (which are grouped into three categories for each POP - survival, basic, and luxury - and these needs being met will do different things, good and bad). A POP's job also dictates its income, which determines both what goods it is able to afford as well as how much tax it will be assessed for and pay to you. So far, this is granular, but pretty normal - the big differences in Victoria 2 are found in how goods are produced, and how they find their way to market.
For production, you've got three methods of increasing complexity. 
First is direct harvesting - each province in the game produces a specific raw good, and the people who live in that province can always default to working in that job, producing that good. Technically you can also have 'aristocrat' POPs who own shares in these and make money from that, but - for gameplay purposes they can mostly be ignored if you want, because they don't need to provide input goods. 
Second method - direct production of secondary goods by POPs called 'artisans'. These are conceptually the simplest job type in the game - they buy ingredients, convert them directly into finished products, sell the products and attempt to live off the profits. In practise, they take some time to learn how to work with; as they buy input goods with their own money, it's very possible to drive them bankrupt with no hope of recovery.
Fortunately, there's also the third type of goods production - factories. These work similarly to farms and mines, in that people can always work in them if there are jobs open. They differ in that they must be built, and they need money in order to operate. That's as much detail as I can go into about their operation, because how they are built and funded differs depending on a variety of things. The laws of the country you're playing as will dictate how that works, and these can and do change during gameplay.

And that's probably the most interesting part about Victoria 2. You've got a whole variety of very detailed systems interacting with each other, but your methods for affecting any of them directly are intentionally fairly broad-spectrum and often limited, while still being impactful enough that it never feels pointless having all the extra detail in there. What I wrote above, about sending artisan POPs bankrupt? It will happen every game unless you're playing a country with very few provinces and thus very few POPs, because you can't tax one group of artisans more or less than anyone else - you set the tax rate for all of your artisans, and all of your government employees, and all of your military officers, and all of your factory administrators, on one slider. And the slider may have a limited range of settings it is allowed to be set to depending on the current government's tax policy. Bail out one large group of starving artisans who have been vital to keeping your under-developed economy producing enough money to pay for educators to raise literacy rates to research new technologies? Two other groups of artisans, plus all of your education workers, will all become hugely more wealthy and start cashing out of their current profession and changing into aristocrats, who then turn around and get upset at you because they're in a different tax setting and can't afford to buy the sailing boats and automobiles that they want to have now.
Oh! And they might have even been able to afford them, but - I didn't get to the other point, which is how goods are sold. That's interesting, too; you've got a global pool of buy orders and a global pool of sell orders (also, a domestic market, then a 'sphere' market; basically, your POPs won't sell all the food they just grew, leave nothing to eat, and then complain about starving, which is nice), and these are matched to each other according to a global ranking system - you get points for 'prestige' (cultural/technological achievements, wining wars, plus a few special events), economic power, and military power. So it's not purely about how much money you can make - you also have to position yourself to be able to spend it, and that's quite clever.

It's disastrously messy at times, but that's when it's at its very best. If you liked the moments in Crusader Kings games where your family nearly got wiped out because of one ambitious second-cousin who had a knife and the keys to the family castle - you might love this one, too. Or you might hate it; the map screen on this game looks nice, but it's not where you play most of the actual game. That's on budget and demographics ledgers.

Victoria 2 is one of the only games I've ever played where a lack of player agency is a constructive component of the gameplay experience. The name of the game with Victoria 2 is influence, not control; in the age of revolutions and extremist ideologies, you can't CONTROL what your people think, who they support or vote for. But you CAN influence it: high affluence and easy access to goods will keep them content and discourage them from radicalizing; focusing on the support of specific parties will make it more likely for those parties to achieve electoral victories even if the rest of your nation doesn't support the ideology they espouse; press censorship can dissuade POPs from becoming class conscious, or full press freedom can be enacted to rapidly liberalize your POPs to encourage liberalization of the government.

You as the player have no direct hand in this - but, again, you do have influence. There is no button to make imports happen, or make your people wealthier, but you can conquer lands to expand your markets, or use soft power (Influence, a mechanic locked to the eight Great Powers) to expand market access in unaffiliated nations, increasing goods access and making them cheaper. If a party loses an election, outside of a monarchy you don't get to void the results of the electoral process, but as previously mentioned you can encourage party support to try to ensure your preferred party wins elections even if your people don't fully support that ideology (just be prepared to pay the price that comes with that in militancy, for an unpopular party ruling the nation). If you want to enact press censorship, or end press censorship, you can't simply decide to do that if your Upper House doesn't support it. The ideology of your voters has to be in line with your goals, OR your people need to be militantly agitated enough to encourage the curmudgeons in your government that their lives would be at risk if they didn't reform. But you can try to expand the vote franchise to change the electoral makeup of your state, as long as you can get the same Upper House to agree to that.

This philosophy of influence without direct control is inspired. Outside of a few extremely micro-heavy elements of the design which do deserve to be criticized, the interconnection of the mechanics makes everything feel seamless while every action is also important. Adding a small nation to your Sphere of Influence could be the difference between a factory remaining open or shutting down due to a lack of markets and available resources. That factory shutting down could be the difference between a portion of your industrial population radicalizing due to unemployment and poor living conditions or remaining pleasantly aloof and supportive of your government. And that can be the difference between a revolution and a calm, prosperous nation.

You never feel like you're fighting your nation, but sometimes you will feel like you're fighting your POPs, struggling to steer them in the way they need to move for your national prosperity. That struggle to influence your own people is the cornerstone of Vicky2, and is one of the most unique, fun, and challenging implementations of indirect player control I've ever had the pleasure of experiencing. Because don't let my Steam hours fool you: I launch this game direct from the .exe, which stops it from tracking properly. I have thousands of hours in this game, and continue to regularly play it today.

Victoria II is objectively one of the greatest strategy games of all time. Developed and published by Paradox Interactive, the game itself is multifaceted and you can engage in many different playstyles while in the game.

The premise is similar to other Paradox-developed strategy games; conquer the world in some sort of historical era. Victoria II, clearly, takes place in the Victorian age, which was defined by colonialism and European dominance.

Gameplay is insanely replayable. You can play until your heart’s content and you will still find things you haven’t done.

Since this is a 12-year old grand strategy game, graphics are irrelevant.

In terms of downloadable content, it can be summarized as “It’s Paradox, there will be DLC”, but, considering this game’s longevity, I was pleasantly surprised to see a relatively low price to purchase all of them.

Price point is debatable. By every measure, Victoria II is one of the best, if not the best game in its genre, however, Paradox is, at the time of review, about to release the long-awaited Victoria III. The game will probably go on sale in the near future, but you don’t have to wait if you don’t want to.

To sum up, Paradox really hit it out of the park with Victoria II, and it is, and will remain, one of the best games of all time.

[u]Victoria 2 – Play it if you have it in your library already, if not you can pass[/u]

After seeing the release date of Victoria 3 (Vic3), I convinced myself that if I was ever going to play Vic2 it would have to be soon. This game was sitting in my library for many years (released in 2010), so I thought why not and gave it a go. 
If anybody does not know, Vic2 is a global strategy game of Paradox Interactive. A cousin, if you will, of Hearts of Iron (HOI) and Europa Universalis (EU). And to be upfront, if this is news to you, I would rather tell you now that simply waiting for Vic3 would be your best bet. 

With people familiar with these series, Vic2 focuses more on the economy and political aspects. At first, the economy seems daunting but with a bit research you can boil down the basics of how the game works. The politics blends well with all aspects of the game which influences the player how to run their country (from libertarian to fascism) with each their pros and cons. Like all paradox games there is a meta of gameplay and once you understand that the game becomes quite manageable.

However, just because it is manageable does not mean the game is easily understandable. There is a lot of data that flies at you in the game, but a lot of that data does not lead to good information directly. For example, will my fabric industry be profitable or where exactly is ‘Mission to Civilize’ in the tech tree? The game does not really tell you directly, but you can find out ‘MANUALLY’. And this is really where the game shows its age, the tool tips are minimal and gives a bread crumb trail for the player to figure out manually. And to be fair, previous paradox games were like this back then. I get a wave of nostalgia from hearts of iron 3 as Germany with Operation Barbarossa, manually controlling the eastern front into Moscow. It took a lot of micromanaging and sifting through data to organize myself to ensure success. And this is what you will be doing if you play Vic2, lots of pausing the game and looking up the wiki to understand what flash point tension means or the difference between liberate country rather than liberate people. 

And hey, there is nothing wrong with that, but this is where Vic2 really shows its age. This game is about 12 years old with two DLCs that came out in 2012 and 2013 (with a lot of sprite packs as well). Those sprites did add some flavour to the game, but the graphics are quite barebones and nothing to write much about.

The last two aspects of the game are the diplomacy and warfare. The diplomacy is the most understandable part of the game due to the limited options you have. The crisis system is a nice touch, but all my games usually ended with white peace (status quo), so nothing really ever came from it unless I as a great power decided to screw around. The game, understandably for the timeline, limits the player’s personal conquest. For example, if you go too far out all the other great powers will team up and slap you down to size with war. 

Warfare is not in the focus for Vic2. And personally, my least favorite part of the game, as you have to game the AI with a very strict meta to make yourself victorious. As my run through with Germany I had to micromanage my death stack around western France even though the battle borders were near Belgium. It doesn’t feel realistic and its just micromanaging your stacks of units to avoid attrition and the other enemy stack that is slightly larger than you. Because 9/10 the bigger unit will win unless you do something silly like attack a unit in the mountains with a river crossing. The ally AI is frustrating at best, with the AI sometimes doing nothing (thanks UK) or just standing right beside you when you desperately need their units to aid in the battle. Otherwise, battles revolve around a simple 0-9 die system. Which if you are unlucky like me, can be rage inducing. 

So overall, if you have this game in your library this may be your chance to play it before Vic3 comes out. And if you do not have it in your library, I would suggest you wait for Vic3* as the game is definitely showing age. 

[i]*As with all Paradox games, I strongly would wait for the at least the first DLC to come out to buy the base game. Paradox first day releases tend to be buggy, unbalanced, and barebones. So give it about a few patches before buying.[/i]

This game is old, clunky and incredibly complex, however I fully believe this is one of the best grand strategy games ever produced. The feeling of slowly educating you population, or slowly building a rail network is incredible. A majority of the things you do in this game are subtle, small background changes to your nation, like setting tax brackets and setting up campaigns for more factory workers, but it is shockly satisfying to see your economy flourish thanks to your indirect hand. The only major gripe I have with the game is that the battle system is complex in places it doesn't have to be, and simple in areas it should be complex. At the end of the day, whoever can throw the most men to die usually wins, and it leads to some unfun wars. All in all, a very, and I say this with heavy emphasis, VERY good time investment to play this game, it will make you think unlike and other strategy game you have played before.
If you've played any Paradox game this oldie is top among them.

For a game that came out in 2010, it still holds entertainment. A great grand strategy game. While most RTS games focus solely on the warfare/expansion aspect, Vicky 2 really focused the game on the economic/social aspect of the era, with a bit of war and expansion and colonisation to top it off. While for many years everyone was firmly believing  it was due a sequel, it finally has one getting ready for release, and I can only hope it does the game justice. 

FYI, for anyone considering playing Victoria 2, just get the DLC, its super cheap, and there are a lot of bug fixes. Also, HPM Mod is essential for some added spiciness.

This is one of Paradox's very best games and there's a reason that Vicky 3 is probably they're most anticipated game in a long time. 

That being said I've never been a fan of the Great Powers mechanic, I feel like it's a good concept just not the best in practice. Colonization is a chore. It's not really fun to play outside of Europe, the US, Japan, and a handful of others. Mods make the game better but I don't really know what is the best way to play. Modded or Vanilla. Immigration is also sort of janky, and the economy is weird. You can understand it, you can see how it is supposed to work. But ultimately you never know what is really going on with it, and if you play multiplayer you can absolutely ruin the world's economy forever. 

Vicky 2 is an incredible game that i have sunk a lot of time into. I'm really excited for 3 because all they need to do is iron out some things. I'll tell you right now though, this game is better than Hoi4.

A reactionary moralist protectionist Vicky player and a mercantilist was teaching a class on Victoria 2 economics.
”Before the class begins, you must get on your knees and worship State Capitalism and accept that it is the most highly-evolved economic philosophy the world has ever known, even greater than Laissez-Faire!”

At this moment, a brave, reformist, laissez-faire liberal author whose voice was heard all over $COUNTRY$ and who had served in over 1848 Jacobin rebel uprisings and understood the necessity of unprofitable factories shutting down and fully supported all economic decision made by the Capitalist POPs stood up and held up a production tab.
”How would you fix this failing industry, pinhead?”
The arrogant professor smirked quite reactionarly and smugly replied “by subsidizing, you stupid Liberal”
”Wrong. The factories need to shut down. If they were valuable enough to spend money on as you say… then they should be profitable by now!”

The professor was visibly shaken, and dropped his chalk and a copy of Treasure by Foreign Trade. He stormed out of the room crying those reactionary crocodile tears. The same tears reactionaries cry for the “unemployed craftsmen” (who today live in such luxury that most can afford Life Needs) when they jealously try to claw the right to build factories from the deserving job creators. There is no doubt that at this point our professor, Benjamin Disraeli, wished he had pulled himself up by his bootstraps and become more than a conservative interventionist. He wished so much that he had a guillotine to execute himself from embarrassment, but he himself had petitioned against them!

The students applauded and all signed up for the Liberal Student's Association that day and accepted the Invisible Hand as their lord and savior. An eagle named “Laissez-Faire” flew into the room and perched atop the $COUNTRY$ Flag and shed a tear on the chalk. The Springtime of Nations event was fired several times, and Robert Peel himself showed up and repealed tarrifs across the country. The professor lost his tenure and was fired the next day. He died of the market crash induced by his subsidies.

We will be free men, as our fathers were.

At its absolute best, it was an ugly, difficult and unrewarding fascism simulator made by war crime apologists in some sort of half baked justification of for the last 200 years of history.

And if that hasn't steered you away, let me go on to recommend you to absolutely not purchase this in 2022 or later.  Infuriatingly unplayable for many reasons.  The basegame is literally just a map that moves through time.  Controlling any game mechanic requires DLC.

Forget this and just wait for 3 which will surely be a much better incredibly complicated fascism simulator made by people with questionable morals and a poor grasp on anthropology that will parcel out everything worthwhile into expense DLC.

Victoria II has interesting ideas that you don't really find anywhere else. The economy alone is intriguing enough to warrant some intrigue.

That being said, this game is old. Both the UI and mechanics (in some cases the lack thereof) stink of older paradox design. Mods are necessary to make the game playable long term (think more than one or two playthroughs), but can't begin to solve all the issues hindering the game. Important game mechanics and more importantly the mods that make this game playable are gated behind owning both DLCs, essentially mandating you add the DLC price into the base cost. And the most interesting mechanics of this game (the economy and POPs) are rarely interacted with, existing more as set pieces than game mechanics. The community around this game can also be incredibly pretentious.

All in all, this game shouldn't be worth playing. And in hindsight it really wasn't. But despite everything I've said I played 78 enjoyable hours of it, which counts for something. Maybe wait for Victoria 3? It's around the corner at this point.

Victoria II is, I have to say, my favourite of the "standard" alt-hist paradox games. (Hoi IV, Ck3, etc.) Though I can't say I've played EU4, it would have to be amazing to beat my love for this game. Unlike Ck3, it focuses more on the nation as a whole, rather than the personal life of the people in the game. And unlike Hoi IV, it focuses a lot more on domestic and internal affairs, rather than being largely consumed by the military aspect.
Victoria II offers so much in terms of gameplay and is able to balance them so well.

Of course, though, the DLC aspect is quite annoying, seeing how the DLC's usually have things that would be best to be in the standard game, though Victoria II does seem less DLC dependent, with the exception of Heart of Darkness and A House Divided, largely because the Greater Flavour Mod is based on Heart of Darkness, which for new players who wish to purchase that DLC, you do need to have A House Divided as well, but I say its worth it for The Greater Flavour Mod.

Vicky 2 is the notoriously complex paradox grand strategy title. Vicky 2 is older and has lots of mechanics added to it. However, this does not subtract the fun if you like tactical EUIV games or the grand strategy of HOI IV. You have to play through a playthrough to figure it out, but it's understandable if you watch what you're doing and maybe google a bit. The older mechanics work pretty decent considering, however the AI is not very smart. You will end every game with quite some bordergore and world wars can break out over the stupidest things. But if you accept this and maybe download a mod like HPM to complement the vanilla game, Vicky 2 still stands strong with the modern Paradox titles. What I personally really love about Vicky 2 is that the surreal World Conquests are hard to do because of the mechanics and that it really focusses on the Great Power competition. You can for example only annex few provinces before you're 'infamy' reaches the 25 mark (basically aggressive expansion and the mark for coalition) and the struggle really focuses on influence spheres and economy. Military is still very important though, but annexing your way to the top will be a less optimised strategy. So to summarise: if you love the tactical politics elements of paradox titles and like to simulate a multipolar world order in which you want to play as a great power, this is the game to get.

Overall Victoria II is an incredibly immersive and enjoyable experience from 1836 to the 1930s. While its mechanics can be complicated and difficult to learn initially, one you get the hang of it you will doubtlessly find yourself enjoying your game as anything from the Two Sicilies, to Prussia, to China.

I've played for many hours on a non-Steam version. The deciding factor in whether or not this game is for you is whether you really, actually care what the political ideology of the player's country is. If you don't, no worries--this one is just probably not for you.

But if you DO give a hoot about the origins of all modern political ideology, from the preservation of the ancien regime to the beginnings of communism, the reaction of fascism, and the dogged perseverance of market liberalism, this game is going to treat you like no other. Its balance of political, economic, and military affairs is completely unique even within Paradox's practically unique genre. Where some games would simply script the WWI event, Paradox's commitment to dynamic unscripted gameplay shines through with the Crisis system, a completely organic way of precipitating the political flashpoints that brought the great alliances into confrontation. The economic simulation is probably the deepest in the history of video games--a system so deep it has been rumored that the devs at Paradox simply forgot how it worked and were unable to figure it out, forcing them to start from scratch for Vic3--apocryphal or not, when you play the game you'll see what I mean, in the best way possible. 

That said, this game has a lot of problems. A LOT of them, actually.
* The completely linear research system is a little lackluster--functional but not really strategic.
* Likewise, the Civilization system is plainly just bad for gameplay, putting all unrecognized powers at a massive and permanent disadvantage--this is understandable given context, but with no other real avenue of gameplay, this just means I don't ever want to play them. Thankfully Vic3 is planning to essentially fix this with its "recognition" and "centralization" systems, adding some variety for non-Eurocentric play.
* The game does not exactly treat slavery & colonization as carefully as I think it warrants. While not exactly gung ho about either topic, colonization in particular is presented in a pretty gamified and ahistorical fashion. Putting players in a Eurocentric role and making it a game mechanic is fine--and thankfully Vic3 will take a more careful approach, but passing over most of it without comment or without really pushing back on the player in any significant way makes it just a little too *fun*, maybe, to scramble for Africa.

This game is one that I always find myself coming back to despite it's several in my opinion glaring flaws. Most of these flaws are a product of the game just showing it's age to put it bluntly. Now that doesn't mean all older games are inherently bad I wouldn't say that at all several of my all time favorites including this game are my favorites because they are older games, and this is what sums up Victoria II for me personally. This game feels wacky to play at times there are bugs and the UI feels dated and clunky and some of the mechanics feel poorly implemented and with a lack of explanation on how to use them. I have found myself overwhelmed with trying to manage rebels and keeping them from rampaging through my country on numerous occasions particularly the jacobins. Diplomacy in this game is rather lackluster with the ai behaving quite terribly and taking very puzzling actions. But the way the ai handles diplomacy isn't as bad as the war ai which is probably the biggest weakness of this game, which can be said honestly for most paradox games. Wars in victoria 2 can feel lackluster and way to easy at times as you can outsmart the ai with absolute ease. But despite all of these things, I still keep coming back and this is one of my most played games ever. The reason why is the fact that Victoria just has a certain charm that most grand strategy games severely lack. The complexity of the industry and economy and the internal politics of the nation are simply captivating and really fun to dive into, I can play entire sessions in the industry screen looking over numbers and designing the perfect economic system. Most modern grand strategy games lack this level of detail and simplify things way too much. I have found very few games that can compete with the level depth detail and charm Victoria II provides. Strongly recommend this game despite it not being perfect and having issues. The 20 dollar price tag is very much worth it, I have put 800 hours into this game and don't regret a single minute.

Victoria II is, perhaps, among the very best games of Paradox. Its sandbox mechanics, although enabling serious divergences from what one would most likely believe to be historically accurate, allow the player to submerge in the environment in which he's meant to lead his nation from its beginning status, that varies tremendously across the map the player moves around, to world hegemony if so he wishes. The economics of the game are truly commendable, for how complex the mechanics behind these are, developing a world, semi-globalised economy that its influenced by the governance of the many nations interacting within the game. Without any mods, however, primarily non-european regions appear to be obscenely unhistorical, with a rather disappointing blind eye for the European colonization of Africa and the instability of Latin America, which were both heavily overlooked.

Vicky 2 is one of the best games I've ever played. Even if he economy is broken by goods multiplication, lacks price differences across the world or ignores the price of logistics, it is still the best and most complex simulator of world economy and industrial revolution I know of. You have many tools to rule your country to let it thrive or boil in turmoil and revolutions. You can liberate nations from their empire oppressors, or you can become the oppressor of the world. Choice is yours, you'll live with the consequences. The AI is quite weak and you can exploit many areas of the game, despite this the game is extremely enjoyable and you can play it anyway you want. You can even chill, let the game play itself, do almost nothing, and you can still have a lot of fun.

I am really looking forward to the next interation of the game, which is already in development.

I am a long term player of Paradox Games, been playing thousands of hours in EU4 and a lot too in CK2, CK3 and HOI4.

I had heard a lot of great things from Vic2 but never had time to really learn the game. All in all Im quite disappointed compared to games like CK2 or EU4.

- The interface itself isn't very user-friendly, you spend a lot of time just looking for the right RGO in a very long list
- many options in the game are useless... Trade could be good, but who manages his stockpiles manually? And Im not sure having so many resources is necessary.
- the game is not balanced, in the sense that with Sweden, Belgium, Denmark, 15 years into the game I had 5 Millions in bank. I just put max taxes, max tariffs and Im golden... without obvious drawbacks
- War is simple, you fight one battle and then the winner just destroys the loser... the losing army only retreats 1 tile, contrarily to the other Pdx titles
....
I could go on and on, but worse, it looks like the replayability is limited. I mean that you have a few choices, but if you go to Africa, the 1870 rush is boring, and before that you would always attack Sokoto... You could play Japan or UK or France.. with slightly different experiences, but nothing compared to CK2 for example. Even EU3 was better.

In the end, Im quite disappointed (but then I paid the game 5 euros with expansions... so still worth it) but I trust Pdx will do something great with Vic3

Victoria II is a Paradox Game at its core, with the pros and cons that carries. Beginning with the pros, this game will allow you to sink hundreds of hours into it, and while it does not change mechanically with each nation, it does allow for a completely different experience on almost every playthrough. I have rarely played a game of Victoria without having fun once I got the hang of it.

That being said, this game also suffers from the classic Paradox shortcomings. The combat and economy management are a little difficult to understand at first, and I would recommend looking up guides online to fully understand them rather than relying on the inadequate game instructions. Furthermore, similar to EU4, this game is basically UNPLAYABLE without buying the two substantial DLCs, both of which are priced significantly higher than any DLC should be for a 12 year old game. Paradox consistently locks what should be free patches and updates behind DLC paywalls, forcing you to spend twice or three times as much as sticker price for the essential mechanical upgrades and fixes found in the final product. Combat in particular without DLC is absolutely horrendous. Furthermore, Paradox relies on their mod community to keep the game fresh after you become an experienced player, as with all their other games, which is both a boon for the player and an indicitement against Paradox's barebones vanilla experience.

Overall, while I would recommend Victoria II, I would advise the interested consumer to wait until there is a good deal available to purchase it so as not to feed Paradox's greed.

The game is good, but in some ways, really comes to life through mods. I started using HPM specifically because of how boring the implementation of the Meiji Restoration was in the vanilla game (literally it was just *push button* -> *become modern*), and the mod really brought a lot of flavor to the game - the only problem is that now you have to wait for ages before you really have a ton of options because of how slow westernization is, and how little you're allowed to do until you're a modernized/great power.

Japan aside, the game is cool, but has some painful limitations. My biggest issue is probably the way armies work in the game? Basically, you have to manually stack tens or hundreds of individual brigades into their armies, moving them across the map until they can join the army you want them in. It's an irksome process. Second to that, though, is how little there is to do sometimes? Depending on how far in the game you are, and what country you're playing, you may or may not have large swathes of the game locked off from you because you're either not westernized or you're not a great power. Lame.

Probably my favorite thing in the game, though, is watching how various nations in the world develop alongside yourself. It's always funny to watch Italy go through revolution after revolution - swapping between fascist, democratic, and socialist governments - or to watch the Mormons break away from the US and form their own nation... lmao. And of course, you yourself could go through those things too. It's just as fun to push your country towards being the first socialist dictatorship in the world, or to release interesting countries from yourself as puppets!

If you're coming from another pdx game and you find this game tough to get into, a couple tips.

1) Every pdx game has sort of a core focus. Eu focuses on map painting, hoi focuses on tactical combat, ck focuses on kingdom management within feudalism. In Vic, you focus on pops and economy. So if it's stressing you out that you're not constantly warring like in eu4, that's perfectly fine.

2) A few fundamental truths about the game. This is set during a period of rapid industrialization. This means... 

- You want your farmers and labourers (people who work the land) to become craftsmen (people who work in factories). Get technology that makes your farms/mines more efficient, and encourage people to join your factories.
- This means artisans (people who make specialized goods prior to industrialization generally speaking) will occasionally starve to death. Don't worry, this is normal. Fuck the poor
- Capitalists are retarded and have no concept of supply chains or making use of your RGOs (a good the province produces), so build your own factories early on, and match them with corresponding RGOs and create supply chains within the same state. After your core economy is established, it's not as important to build anymore (save for new techs). To do this, you need a government that allows you to build factories (State Capitalism)
- One slightly less intuitive thing about this game is that being really successful doesn't correlate quite as strongly with how big your country looks on a map compared to other pdx titles. You want prestige, industry score and military score, so things like literacy rates, technology, population density, good raw materials like iron/coal are more useful than blobbing if you want to become stronk.
- If your factory isn't getting a critical resource, there's a very good chance that its in very high demand on the world market. Check the trade screen and connect the dots.
- Everything is incentive based in this game. In eu4 and ck3, you can just conscript people into your army at the drop of a dime if you have the money. In vic2, you need to convince people that joining the army is worthwhile, so drag that slider up!

Hope these tips help.

This is the strategy game I've been waiting over 40 years for! It has every element I want in a game like this without becoming so complex that it gets boring.

You have to manage your economy through taxes, trading, building factories etc, whilst keeping a close eye on your military/infrastructure expenditure. Balancing them is fun not annoying.
When it comes to military conquest (which these games invariably do), you need to keep an eye on your unit attrition and reinforcement levels, whilst also making sure they are actually getting supplied, and all of this while trying not to annoy the other 'Great Powers' and causing them to go to war with you. Oh, and don't forget to make sure your fleets are maintained to a high standard. We don't want to be going into a battle with more holes than a sieve in the ships :)

You can try to influence smaller countries/empires to bring them into your sphere of influence and making sure that other empires don't do similar, using a few sneaky tricks available (ban embassy etc).

I think the only thing I would maybe change, if programming allowed, would be the ability to fight your own battles on a small map. I find it frustrating that I can get beat down by a much smaller, less experienced army, but that's a very small issue in my opinion.

All in all, I have to say that I am really enjoying this game and I can foresee many more hours put into it.

Don't be fooled by the low number of hours I've played on this Steam account, I probably have around 100 hours on this game from before I created this account. In my opinion, Victoria II is the best of Paradox's grand strategy games. There's just something about it. Perhaps it's how involved and in-depth the economy is. Or maybe how complex and deep the political system is. Or maybe it's the population system that breaks down the opinions of each specific group in your society (artisans, laborers, aristocrats, bureaucrats, etc.) and their attitude toward your governance. In reality, it's a combination of these things and more that make this game such a timeless masterpiece. If you've played EU4 and/or CK2 or any of the other Paradox grand strategy games and haven't played this one, I would highly recommend it.

[h1][u]After over 1600 hours review:[/u][/h1]

for me the rating is to low for this game imo. Thats why I let some opinion out of my head:

[u]Summary first:[/u]
- alternate history strategy game for connaisseures of realm-creation and people which have pleasure in leading a 
  country of their choice to glory or dominion or to something they like it to be.
- each part of the mechanics feels logical and useful (esp. with the community mods!!!) and has some kind of depth.
- immensly immersive in my eyes. You get a certain feeling for evey step u make into the modern world with plenty 
  technologies, new troops, industrial goods or even populations culture
- interesting and quiet complex population simulation mechanics from poor to rich with interests in politics, social 
  reforms, rebellion, religion, etc. They have own money, they immigrate, they have needs. All like 'easy to learn and not 
  so hard to master' ;)
- A.I. is solid. Sometimes they make some stupid wars they cant win or dont get all out of they military potential but the 
  A.I. also can suprise with some good ideas and clever timing to get their goals done.
- I recommend to buy this game in sale just because its these times where games seem to stay full price for 10 years or 
  more. 
- I highly recommend to get community-mods like Pop Demand Mod (pdm) or PoPs of Darkness to get so much more out 
  of this pearl
- i also recommend to use lets plays to reduce the time to get the basics immensly. After that u only need to check up the 
  wiki from time to time.

I got a lot from the game and want to give something back with this esp. after seeing the rating going down for vic2 recently and for me for reasons that not allways concerning the game.

Leaving [i]Paradox[/i] and all the talking aside, this game is still some great piece of gaming experience for the ones who love to create a what-if-history-would-have-been-like-this-realm. Its perfect for making up an own story while an alternating history is happening in the world around u. Imagine to have an Northamerica with balanced powers of Mexico, Confederates and the Union States. What happens if China becomes an industrial Power like 1870 already? How about Brazil being not so friendly and tries to build up an imperial reign over full south america? 

For those kind of ideas u need some hours to get into the enough to have control over all mechanics which are going some kinda deep but not really overwhelmingly detailled. I watched a let's play for like 3 episodes and had barely all in my head to let it roll.
After that i had a pretty nice time trying out stuff of all various kinds. The game also offers a nice input of historical events and understanding what the world was like back the days. In a time the gap between the cultures and technologies vastly extended to a point where war became a common mechanic to gather might, the rise of idiologies, birth of nations and the power of production u can pick out one idea of the future and try to make it happen.

To get this done u have to build up a healthy country with strong economy and military. Most time thats just one side of the coin. Good relations to other countries and Alliances will give u advantages directly or open up opportunities in the first place. Allies give u goods u need to get ur factories working or to build troops, they support u in battle or give u access to their ports for ur seacraft units and more thought they sometimes seem to act somekinda strange when it comes to participating in wars or cancelling treaties a bit suprisingly. About artificial Intelligence: Dont expect high end A.I. that's only to beat when u play like an real general. The game gives u many information and even more information is to be found in the wikis what can be a little bit overwhelming in the beginning. It takes maybe 20 hours of play or so to fully understand what is really important to look at and what is not so worth to break ur head bout. 

All in all this game is nicely balanced to get ur plans done and have fun.
If u want to proof ur genius - no. 
If u like to just drop in and play some war - don't buy it.
But if u want to be slightly challenged (even more if u want to beat the greatest powers like France,Great Britan, The USA or Germany) and are willing to invest some time while u are getting a historical interesting insight to a not even so far away past u may get this game when its in sale. Sure - for me even 50€ would have been ok. But if u are not sure... its on sale at leats 2 times a year for like 20€ with all dlcs. :)

Last but very important point:
Hats off to the mod-makers. The basegame is great but a bit slim after u got into it for some time.
Look up the extending Mods like Pop Demand Mod or PoPs of Darkness.
They immensly enrich the game with many many improvements concerning A.I., Varity, balancing.
I highly recommend to play the game with these mods if u like to have the full vic2 experience.

PROS: 
- One of Paradox's older titles yet it still offers better internal country mechanics than titles that are 8-10 years newer than itself. This game is not focused on warfare and conquest unlike other paradox titles, and being the number 1 power doesnt require conquering the whole world
- That being said the warfare in this game is quite similar to other paradox titles, yet due to the natural progression of technology, battles have around 3 distinct phases in the game. warfare in 1836 is nothing like that in 1900.
- The fundamental feature about Victoria 2 are the POPs which represent a certain demographic of people in your country. Managing the wants and needs of your pops and that of your nation is the key here.
- Plethora of mods available which helps fix the amount of flavour for many countries, allows for alternate history, border fixes, and in some cases even the economy. HPM, HFM, The Grand Combination are just a few of the many great mods out there.
CONS: 
- The game shows its age especially for those who are used to newer titles such as CK3. The UI is quite outdated and the game does not tell you a whole lot about what is going on. (This lack of information is what leads to people saying you need an economics degree to understand what happens in game). The economy in this game and the world market are also quite broken, especially in the late game, which also leads to frustration.
- Warfare in the late game is also extremely tedious as the size of armies and the amount of people you can mobilize for war will be in the millions. The units in game are organized in brigades of 3000 men, which means manually moving ~1000 units in some cases.
- The 2 expansions, A Heart of Darkness and A House Divided are absolutely necessary, do not torture yourself by playing base game Victoria 2.

Had it in my library for a while, decided to get into it for the first time over the past week.

Its pretty addictive and is a solid game, but I can't recommend it just because its essentially just EU4 but not as polished.

It did come before EU4, so its a shame the game is still pretty broken over 10 years after its release. For example, demand for resources will get so high (and stay so high) that literally nobody but the GPs can have access to them, and it leads to a death spiral of 'nobody else can be a GP because they cant train troops, and they cant train troops because they arent a GP'.

Silly stuff like that on top of lots of crashes and the combat that, while good for its age, feels dated at this point, as it was essentially copy-pasted into EU4 and really hasn't aged well I feel.

That said, the concept has a ton of potential. It just needs abit of an overhaul and some polish and it can really shine as the best Paradox Grand Strategy game of the bunch. Its looking like Paradox has every intention of doing that with Victoria 3, which is very good news, but that also means that if you are looking to get into the franchise, you really should just wait.
What make the game fantastic and horribly addicting. Is how well designed and balanced it is. Who ever coded this is extremely intelligent.

If you are a massive fan of the Victorian/post-Victorian eras, managing a complex economy system, manipulating diplomatic situations in your favour, and/or just outright strategy for a great empire, you will love this game, as it has those things combined into a little nice package from late 2010.

If your PC can't run this game with its default settings, you can look up a guide on how to get Victoria II running on your (probably) electrical potato of a computer.

When you first play this game, your head will probably be on the verge of exploding when you see the UI for the first time, but don't worry, it's not as bad as you think it is, and it can be relatively easy to learn if you watch CallMeEzekiel's guides on the basics, the economy management, and the military strategies on how to be successful in this time period of turbulent change and revolution.

If you wish to get the best bang for your buck, I'd recommend you buy the complete edition on sale for £10.30 ($14.73 if you're from the US, or 14,73€ if your country uses the Euro in the EU).

Victoria 2 is one of my favourite games of all time. It's fun, has a high learning curve and shows huge potential. Some things are lacking and should be improved upon though.

[b]pros[/b]
++ population system
++ soundtrack
++ a lot of countries to choose from. You can even play as Luxemburg...if you want to.
+ addicting gameplay.
+ supports mods that offer even more content. Installing HPM or HFM is recommended
+ high learning curve with a lot of payoff

[b]cons[/b]
- The crisis system, the political parties and the decisions need more polish
- somewhat broken economy
- Annexing regions cost should be scaled and depend on each region's worth. Right now it isn't. Also, annexing remnant parts of a region should cost less if you already own other parts of it.
- no unit template to replenish units
Finally I can tax the rich
