It's got rewarding gameplay, no arbitrary mana or anything else to get in the way of the meat of the game: a Victorian economics simulator. It's by no means perfect, but by far the best Paradox game I've played, successfully creating a rewarding experience with multiple different ways to play. The only two complaints are that two DLCs are essential for the game, and it is a little bit rough around the edges. It's a game that everybody should at least become acquainted with and the true gem of Paradox's titles, no matter how bad Victoria III turns out to be. Every Paradox "historical" game I've played, I have been disappointed with and regretted buying, but not Victoria II.

It is somewhat playable without dlcs, if you choose to play as one of the 8 starting majors or easy to be majors like Prussia. Without dlcs, playing as uncivilized is pretty hard, even if you play as Japan since not only westernizing requires the nonsense amount of 50 Military Power Projection but the aforementioned starting majors/mid-game majors tend to form alliance blocs that pretty much c*ckbl*ck you for the rest of the game, not to mention the infamy system with fixed values for each CB, conquest being the most expensive with flat 20 infamy(remember, no dlcs), the awkward political and social reforms system, endless waves of rebels in late-game, Great Britain with 663 brigades by 1870 (half of them provided by indian pops), national focii tied availability tied to the millions of primary culture pops([i] which ties you, if lucky, to 2-3 focii for pretty much the entire game or only 1 since assimilation rates are awfully slow [/i]) and the classic Yellow Prussia.

With dlcs, it may get less painful to play but still very unpleasant in some regards.

There had been a century of iron and blood, where the poor struggles for survival and the rich struggles to shove off waves of these consciously property-less people. A century of great glory to the glory-seeker and great anguish to the glory-sought, where paper and pen could define collectives of peoples and tables-hosts of diplomats determine the fate of a nation. Where engines roar their outcry unto the vast and open world, where mankind finds its future lying not in the hand of any monotheistic deity. A century of hope and progression in their uttermost forms, a century with despair and degradation occurring to their widest extents. This century sees humankind growing faster than ever before, producing more material and wisdom than any other time. But it sees too the massacre of the people, with scale and brutality eclipsing all that precedes them, happening every moment, to every people of the world. Let us be content, then, to say that this century has seen the creation of the world. Yes, we must still celebrate this century; because in essence, this century has never yet end.

[b]"Your people are your most important resource and are basically the driving engine of Victoria 2"[/b], says the Basic Population Tutorial (one of around 30 in-depth, in-game tutorial chapters). After 3 hours playing through the entire tutorial, this simple sentence really undersells the extremely ambitious simulation in this game.

The sentence is describing the concept of a population unit in Vic2 (also Pop or POPs). Each of these represent one of 12 professions a segment of your population can have, from soldier to aristocract. [b]Each of these is described in an astounding amount of detail[/b] from militancy, class-consciousness, literacy and unemployment to a breakdown of its finances to dozens of needs that can be not, partially or fully sated to the individual ideologies and current political issues they care about; their likelihood to promote or demote to other jobs or economic classes or migrate to and from your country.

Is that not enough socio-economic-political simulation for you? What if I tell you [b]your country won’t simply have a “artisan” pop but as many artisan pops needed to represent the unique combination of culture, religion and profession for each[/b] of them?! Again, with every pop being fully unique in all the characteristics presented above. 

Is that, somehow, still not enough socio-economic-political simulation for you? What if I tell you there are [b]over 100 countries in the game, each comprised of one or more states (each state then comprised of one or more provinces)[/b] - and that each and every one of those provinces can and will have its own roster of uniquely-described, uniquely-evolving populations each with the full set of details mentioned above.

So you’re finally convinced that there’s a fair bit of depth in the effort this game takes to represent every segment of your population? As the first sentence in this review pointed out, this is only the beginning. [b]Populations are the building block of a deeply interconnected economic system with around 40 individual materials and goods[/b] being produced and refined and the economy itself is only half of the trade market, which Victoria 2 has two of: one for local nation and coalition trading and another for international trade. Each market is fully simulated by stockpile supply and demand, with money itself being subjected to things such as inflation or being loaned at interest by national banks.

So what makes this the ultimate socio-economic political simulator, rather than just a very complex strategy board game with tons of individual moving pieces to it? It’s the fact that, [b]much like real life governance, you cannot influence any of those things directly[/b]. There isn’t a button to create new pops or make a certain pop less likely to revolt by spending resources. All you can ever (for the most part) are macro decisions in each simulated aspect of the game and wait and see how it plays out as the wheels keep turning.

Are you convinced now that this one of, if not the most ambitious world-scale simulation game ever made? What if, just for good measure, I throw in [b]the full 4X gamut of features too[/b] from ground, naval and air combat to establishing colonies to rich diplomatic options from colonization to superblock mechanics? You know, just in case you want to throw all those pops into a wargame (which you can, as you’d expect as every military unit is backed to a Pop unit).

The one thing I’ve found lacking so far is the soundtrack - even only playing through the tutorial, I’ve listened to some of the individual tracks play two or three times already, let alone in the 20 or 30 hours you’ll be playing the game for. I plan to turn this weakness into a strength though - the baroque-esque music fits perfectly with the Victorian setting and I’ll probably just turn the music off and dive into my mostly-untapped collection of classical music instead (shoutout to Musopen and co).

So far, other than the introduction video being a bit glitchy, this [b]works flawlessly on Linux[/b] through Steam Play (Wine/Proton).

As a game developer with very specific tastes and a lot of unfulfilled ideas, it’s not everyday that I come across one of my dream game ideas being sold for dirt-cheap,  fully realized and much better than anything I could ever hope to do on my own. The only thing I could wish for was that this covered more periods of history or that it had support for generating random worlds with each playthrough - thankfully, even this seems to have been brought to life by the [b]thriving fan community, with around 100 mods released on 2021 alone[/b].

This is a game for players who like spending 2 hours to learn the controls and 10-15 hours to learn the basics of diplomacy, economy, etc.
This game generates a ton of different cool and sometimes strange situations.
This is a slow game, so dont expect fast-paced gameplay and 15 min matches.
Interface is sometimes dumb, but mostly ok.
This game is similar to Hearts Of Iron 4, but its a lot more oriented on political life, economy and social management. You can spend a lot of time adjusting taxes, fees, spendings, researches, etc.
This game has a lot of mods, which i havent tried yet.
You should probably buy it with A House Divided and Heart of Darkness DLCs, not only because they add navy forces, colonization, international crises, US Civil War starting point and much more, but because they fix a lot of bugs you might encounter in vanilla victoria II.

8/10

I can say, one of the best strategy games I have ever played! The balance between conflict, politics and the economy makes this one of the most atmospheric and tense games ever. Initially when I started, the game looked very complicated and was very difficult to get into. After playing for a few hours when you begin to understand the basic functions of the game, you get used to it. World wars are done very well in Vicky II, with countries throwing everything they have at you to ensure victory. Post-war economic recoveries are also done brilliantly with war exhaustion increasing by 20% at the end of a Great War, which recovery can speed up with reduction in taxes and tariffs. One of the best nations to play is no doubt the German Empire! You can become very powerful as you approach the scramble for Africa in the 1880's and the beginning of the 20th century. 

DLC is a must-have in this game! It massively improves your experience and many mods depend on it. Trust me, you do not want to experience yellow Prussia and the endless ear-drilling when you build forts and railroads! The two compulsory ones are Hearts of Darkness and A House Divided. Forget the other ones as they do pretty much nothing to improve your gameplay.

Overall, this game deserves a grand 10/10!

This game deserves a sequel, but PDS teases us with how they say they can't improve upon it.  The game is typical Paradox, challenging but addicting.  It has a complex world trade simulator that is full of potential but difficult to master.  It has a diplomacy system that requires you to engage the world, otherwise you might find yourself isolated without allies. And it shares the military mechanics as its big sister game Europa Univeralis III and its niece Europa Univeralis IV.  Of the core games that Paradox Interactive is known for, this is the last one that hasn't seen a sequel and its much deserved.

Victoria II is a good game, however I'm a bit hesitant to recommend it in 2021. The game is extremely deep and filled with every statistic imaginable about the nations of the 1800s. Unfortunately, that depth is a bit of a double-edged sword as the game has a very steep learning curve and very little in the way of helpful tutorials. Plan to spend time learning the mechanics of the game on wikis and Youtube before jumping in. If you are coming from more modern Paradox games, expect to be a bit disappointed with the UI, visual cues, and general polish of the game, especially without DLC or mods. With all that being said, the time period is fascinating, the gameplay is deep, and the scope of the game is immense. There are endless ways to play and each play through will likely be unique. While Victoria II is good and deserves a recommendation, I'd ultimately suggest waiting for its recently announced successor, Victoria III, as it will likely be far more accessible to newer players.

+ Great setting/time period
+ Excellent music
+ Great depth
+ Massive replayability

- Cumbersome UI
- Poor tutorials and guidance
- Dated visually
- Needs DLC/mods to be compelling
- Repetitive events

To be fair, you have to have a very high IQ to understand Victoria 2. The strategy is extremely subtle, and without a solid grasp of Victorian politics and economics most of the gameplay will go over a typical player's head. There's also references to the tragedies associated with colonization, which is deftly woven into the storyline- several references to Dr Livingstone's exploration of the African continent exist too. The fans understand this stuff; they have the intellectual capacity to truly appreciate the depths of these events, to realize that they're not just historically significant- they say something deep about LIFE. As a consequence people who dislike Victoria 2 truly ARE idiots- of course they wouldn't appreciate, for instance, the humor in the line "Rock me in my cradle" in the cotton event, which itself is a cryptic reference to Charles Dickens' "Bleak House" . I'm smirking right now just imagining one of those addlepated simpletons scratching their heads in confusion as Johan Anderson's genius wit unfolds itself on their computer monitors. What fools. how I pity them. 😂

And yes, by the way, i DO have a Victoria 2 tattoo. And no, you cannot see it. It's for the ladies' eyes only- and even then they have to demonstrate that they're within 5 IQ points of my own (preferably lower) beforehand. Nothin personnel kid 😎

I love this game. Granted, there are problems with the base game that make it hard to enjoy, but some awesome modding communities have fixed most of those problems. Personally, I play the PopDemandMod but many others enjoy the Historical Project Mod. Both of these mods fix the main issues of the game that I would complain about (mainly the economy and rebels).

I love the idea this game presents which captures the time period. European powers becoming more and more global and wars becoming more bloody combined with new philosophical ideas causing revolutions around the world have shifted global politics away from conventional war like what happened during and prior to the Napoleonic Era and now focuses on economics, industry, and influence.

You can dominate this game, in theory, with virtually no invasions and be a totally pacifist nation. Just by building up your industry and your influence, by sphering lesser nations, you can become a global power or superpower. Or you can utilize your new industry and economic wealth to wage global war and become the greatest conquerer in history.

Plenty of games claim you can "do anything" and win the game but seldom do they have reasonable means of actually delivering that promise. Civilization games, for instance, have a similar score system that allows you to win by the end of the game. It, in reality, doesn't ever get utilized much since your neighbors can easily conquer you or overwhelm you if you're too focused on the long game. Those conquests, even if you are ignored, grant more points to your opponents than you would gain just being pacifist.

This game allows for far more flexibility. You absolutely can be pacifist, or at the very least anti-war, and become the #1 Great Power. You can conquer the entire map (or most of it, it's a HUGE map). You can do virtually anything and win in a variety of ways.

Even though it falls short in its attempt at complex politics and economics it delivers far more than what was ever though possible when this series first began. As of writing this review Victoria 3 was announced and it aims to deliver even MORE than this game. I am anxious but excited for the prospect and I would recommend THIS game to anyone who is potentially interested in the upcoming Victoria 3.

Play this game first, save your money, and get feel for this type of game. This sort of game is about the LONG term not the short term. You'll never just sit down and have a 1hr session. This game is going to take lots of time to get into and once you do you'll be sucked into it. So, get a feel for the flow of this sort of game so when Victoria 3 comes out you'll know if you like it or not. Hope you enjoy!

FYI: The in game tutorial sucks, go on YouTube for better run downs.

Literally nothing you can do except sit in fast forward and wait for arbitrary numbers in spreadsheets to go up and down without your (obvious) input.
Only way to "win" or progress is following a guide that recommends actions without a logical reason behind them; click this, click that, boom, you get this specific pop up and your numbers go up. Why? No idea. It seems arbitrary without a basis in history. Why does encouraging clergymen help the Japanese Empire change their constitution to fit a more Western model; and why is that the only way that can happen? No explanation, no reason, nothing but intransparent and overcomplicated game systems intertwining in a mess of lack of player agency and basically looking at a world that a child controls with a dice roller where you might or might not have an impact, who knows.

What do you do in the game?
I honestly don't know.
You pause the game and have zero choices. You can change your ruling party for no tangible effects, you can press a lot of things, adjust a lot of options, but in the end it feels like everything that is happening is predetermined and you're a monkey pressing at a non-touch screen monitor expecting things to change on your command.

All the choices you have are greyed out until something hyper specific comes around to change that, and every other gameplay option is just sitting there in fast forward waiting for nothing to happen at all.

I wished for a historical strategy game to roleplay in as a history nerd, and got something that has three useless buttons for me to interact with and otherwise just sit and watch literally nothing happen, no agency, no choices, no nothing. No gameplay.

But then, I decided to go through the tutorials, don't get me wrong I had already gone through the intro but I didn't pay much attention and figured I could do it on my own. I want to love Paradox games for their immersive historical setting and some interesting mechanics. Diplomacy and Politics mechanics are amazingly good, economy and population could be better, but are OK.

But I can not recommend this game because of its very important flaws:

The military and battle system is really bad and makes no sense. It consist on just moving your army to an enemy province, wait until it is controlled and move to the next province. It takes a long time, it is tedious and boring. Winning battles do little for wining the war. There are no strategic points to take/defend. It does not allow you either to make any strategy. The AI does not know what to do, and just move around trying to take some unprotected province, without presenting any challenge to the player. I remember old MS-DOS games that were much better. 

Other mechanics like building consist in clicking a lot of buttons when the option becomes available. The only difficulty is to not forget to click update in any of your many provinces. This can be very annoying.

I had actually much more fun modding and changing the things in the game that I find wrong than actually playing. But Some things I can not change like the dumb AI behavior.

Maybe Paradox will improve and eliminate some of these flaws in the future, and will make great games to enjoy. Until them, I can not completely recommend this game.

I love this game and have put far more hours into it than steam declares.
It is a complex geopolitical simulator which, if you enjoy map and spreadsheet games like I do, you will enjoy for hours. 
The UI is fairly intuitive but the underlying mechanics are complex and will need some experience to understand, even after 1k+ hours I would not claim to know them. 
What I love most about this game is that it has no defined goal, you can play as any nation and create your own goals and build you own nation. It is a 'game you do not have to play' which means that the basics just run themselves, your decisions are what matter and they have massive impact on the game but it is not apparent. 
On your first play though, I would advise choosing an irrelevant nation and just learning the mechanics. Conquer the world type strategies are not applicable in this game. Learning and understanding the mechanics are far more important as you go. 
The worst part of the game is the 'complete cluster f*** of war'. It is exciting, but it will cost you thousands if not millions of your people, You will be so diverted by combat that you will forget many of your best plans, and even perhaps your greatest and most experienced armies. I find this realistic based on reading enough history to understand that sometimes a message does not get there and an army does not move.
I explain my stupidity with a realistic message does not get through scenario, because I find the cluster f*** fairly true. This game puts you in the position of government and does not hold your hand. 
You can, quite easily, lose a war to internal rebellion when on the cusp of victory. 
If you want an experience that will make you pace about wondering whether a war is worth the losses, this is the one, if you want a role play experience in the 1836-1936 era, this is the one.
If you want an easy to understand, low barrier to entry type game, with little effort, this is not the one for you.
This game is great for those that like proper strategy, map and spreadsheet style, with complex and deep economics and Naval/Military strategy. I ruined one of my wars because I failed to secure enough supply and the market crashed so non of my army had ammunition or weapons. 
This game is my favourite, without a doubt. I can chill as NZ, AUS or IRE, or wage war as France or Russia. Some of my best runs of this game have been as Ethiopia or Persia. 
You find your place and your fun if you like this type of game. I have not found a better geopolitical sim

With Vicky 3 coming up I thought it would be time for me to finally write a review of one of my all time favourite games.

Victoria 2 is a wonderful game by itself, but it is so much better with Mods. The modding community grew quite a bit over the last two years, and there are many mods that could be games on their own - and there's no hurting in starting the game with mods, especially if you play those who just add to the basegame; HPM, GFM or TGC are those that instantly come to mind for me. Everyone who owns this game should definitely try those!

That said: the game is a lot better with the Expansion Packs, even though yellow Prussia became a well-loved meme over the years the base game has many flaws that only really get weeded out by the Expansion Packs.

Forever the quintessential, prototypical grand strategy game in my eyes. Classic. Play with mods for optimal experience.
Positives: Factories, markets, time period, UI, battle mechanics, unit types/variations. map, flavor events. Envelopes you in hours of splendid map painting zen, yet also gives you plenty of ways to enjoy yourself without blobbing if that's what you'd prefer. 
Negatives: Diplomacy and interactions with foreign countries leave much to be desired. Naval warfare is a mess. Sometimes a bit too much railroading.

I originally bought this game on a whim - because it was on sale and I was buying Crusader Kings 3.

As of writing, the time I've spent on Vicky 2 is 139x the time I've spent on CK3. It's quite addictive.

I don't think it's too intensive. My computer is about as old as the game and can run it fairly well unless there are millions of troops on the screen. 

I highly recommend playing it with both DLCs AND the Historical Project Mod (HPM). HPM essentially just makes the whole game better: adds more African and South American nations, adds more events for a wide array of nations and improves colonisation. My only gripe is that it makes some events take longer to achieve. For example, if you want to form Germany or Italy, you need the 'Nationalism and Imperialism' technology, while in vanilla you needed to meet the requirements and could form either in the late 1930's.

I like much about the game, so here are the immediate cons for the unmodded game with DLC. (HPM fixes some of these)

-Most uncivilised nations are boring.
-Not much to do in South America unless you're Brazil and even then, not much.
-Economy makes no sense.
-Awful tutorial.
-Late game can get boring/frustrating since you're either too strong for anyone to pose a threat or you're too weak to become a Great Power.

There's a reason people play Germany, Italy or Japan. They have a lot to keep you busy and it's very easy to become overpowered as any of them (well, mostly Germany and Japan) so you can bully other nations.

I definitely would recommend!

(You only need Hearts of Darkness and A House Divided DLC. Buy them on sale.)

Firstly I love this game because I can play my own country - Transvaal.
Secondly I love this game because it focus on what I find interesting - governing a country.
PS:  Transvaal was actually named the ZAR = Zuid Afrikaansche Republiek meaning the South African Republic. It later became the Transvaal Province in South Africa.
Criticism: The game doesn't make provision for the Anglo-Boer War, one of the most important events in South African history and the very event that ended the existence of the Boer Republics (ZAR & Oranje) to merge with the British colonies of the Cape of Good Hope and Natal to form > South Africa.
By the way, Oranje is actually the OVS (Oranje Vrij Staat), that later became the Vrystaat (Free State) province of South Africa.
Where do these names come from? Transvaal means "Across the Vaal River". Oranje Vrij Staat (actually Trans Oranje Vrij Staat) means: "The state free of British rule on the other side of the Oranje River".
We just couldn't get away from those bloody British! LOL

If you like: playing "the great game" of empires and using your tangled influence network and alliances to spread your empire, playing as old empires (britain, spain, russia, portugal, the dutch) and bringing them to the modern age, playing as (historical) new empires to usurp the balance and sew chaos, colonizing new lands (but don't like EU$ (oh sorry, 4)), and beating the tar out of china, then this game is great.

If you don't like: Combat that can be decided by a literal dice-roll (outnumbered enemy, better leaders, the only advantage is they're on a hill and you lose by a mile because you got a bad dice-roll), trying to create non-historical new empire (good luck trying to save mexico), and just generally wonky alliances that throw everything through a loop (why the hell is the ottoman empire allied with Britain?) then avoid this game at all costs. The combat alone has given me literal headaches.

Most people start their adventure with strategy games by playing one of a Total War's. Then after geting bored
with simple strategy games they want something a little bit more complicated. So they start playing games like "Heart's of Iron IV" or "Europa Universalis IV". But some are not satisfied with them. They get bored with lack of possibility to chage world in more way's then just map painting. After all what's the point of playing as Third Rich and defiting the allies, when only thing it achives is giving you more factories and defiting your enemies? What about holocaust? Or planned colonization of Labensraum? Or global aftermaches of Axis wining WWII? For people that ask such questions let me introdiuce you with Victoria 2. Amount of things you can influence is simply stagering. 
Complex economic simulations? Check 
Complex social simulations? Check
Politics? Check
Even thou game is practically speaking UNFINISHED, mod's like HPM or HFM solve every problem you might have with the game after understending how to play (witch is quite hard). Game have infinite replayablity. 11/10

If you like map painting, being the best at industry, and colonialism? Then this is the game for you. You can give people rights, and make their lives better, or worse. Create awesome nations and some nice throw backs with some great mods like HPM and HFM.

THERE ARE TWO sides to my feelings about this game: the side that really really likes this gmae, and the side that absolutely fucking HATES paradox interactive.

Paradox Interactive is the publisher of most games like this you see floating around the steam store. Their most notable titles are Crusader Kings, Europa Universalis, Victoria, and Hearts of Iron. theyre generally high quality games with good production value. but thats where their good things end.

every game is treated as a "launchpad" for several "major" dlcs, all of which's contents should absolutely have been included in the original release of the game. Often times, these expansions dont even change much, and they ask for a baseline of FIFTEEN DOLLARS for each one. it costs nearly THREE HUNDRED USD to buy all of the dlc for crusader kings II, even though that game is free.
This isn't the thing that really got me riled up, though. It's the fact that paradox acquired one of my favorite games of all time, Prison Architect, and within a few months they churned out a garbage DLC like they usually do. 

I really like the games that paradox puts out but i seriously cannot and will not continue to support their business model.

I recently purchased Victoria 2 when I saw the Victoria 3 announcement, and I must say that as a vet of other Paradox games (HOI4, CK2, CK3, EU4) that this might just be my favorite of them all. There is so much to the economic, diplomacy, politics, population, etc. systems that it makes the game very unique and detailed. There is a learning curve, moreso than the other Paradox games, but that also is what makes it great. I'll plan on posting a beginner tutorial here soon, but I hope Paradox doesn't try to dumb down Victoria 3.

All in all it's a great game and I highly recommend. Are there some accessibility features that I got spoiled with in EU4 (macro builder), yes, and are the graphics a bit dated, yes, but content/setting wise this game is very deep and I can honestly say I think it will become my favorite Paradox game after a few hundred more hours :).

Paradox have clearly come a long way from this decade old game but this game provides a solid and fun core gameplay experience, which is why this game is definitely recommended

It's difficult, messy, has a dated UI, god awful army management, opaque economy mechanics, and yet it's still one of the finest strategy games ever made.

Most civilization management games feel like Risk with more buttons, but Victoria 2's population mechanics which simulate wealth, trade, production, and culture help to create an immersive in-game world that feels less like a board game and more like a world that's been lived in. It's a world filled with populations who are responsive to your policies, instead of just mana and manpower. When you recruit armies, you source soldiers directly from your provinces; when you close factories, your newly unemployed workers may revolt or migrate away; newly conquered territory can't just be magicked into core states, and national identities are resilient and reluctant to assimilate.

The core vision of Vicky 2 is a world based on dynamic systems that feel like they exist beyond just player interaction. It doesn't entirely succeed, but it's a damn good attempt; here's hoping that Victoria 3 can fly its banner high.

Victoria 2 is a "good enough" game. 
It has many flaws; it frequently crashes and the AI has no idea what it is doing half the time, leaving most games to becoming ahistorical, which isn't a bad thing necessarily.
It is a fun strategy games with many nations that are different, for example as Germany/Prussia you would play politics with your neighbors and wage wars, as Japan you would seek to become a superpower and avoid the tides of war as best as you can. Lastly you can play as some South American or Middle Eastern country and bide your time, slowly becoming a superpower.

VICTORIA 3 CONFIRMED!!!

The UI is confusing. The economy breaks late into the game. The learning curve is exceptionally steep. The tutorial: practically nonexistent. 

It's still the best grand strategy Paradox has ever made. 

This is the only game, in my opinion, which actually feels like you are running a *real* country, not just a paper representation. Every solider, artisan, peasant, capitalist, craftsmen, all the parts of a population (POPs) are modelled with needs and wants, which must are fulfilled by the world economy. Dozens of goods flow in and out of the world market, the price of said goods being affected by supply and demand. Elections are modelled based on the actual political leanings of the POPs, immigration, internal migrations, birth rate, death rate are represented. Your nation is not merely a entity on the map, it is the product of it's diverse peoples- just like in real life. It's incredible to see your nation turn from a rural backwater to a strong industrialized state- or just as interesting to see in crumble as you deal with a collapsing economy, an angry populace and an ineffective government. 

Let's all hope that Victoria 3 takes these principles to heart, and delivers a worthy successor to this masterpiece of a game.

This game is extremely fun despite being pretty old. It's one of the few games that actually cover the Nineteenth Century, which is a shame, because it's actually a immensely interesting period. Its strongest feature is the economics system, which is surprisingly in-depth and dynamic (note that the Pop Demand Mod, which greatly improves the economy, among other things). The simulation of political and social reform and development is also very interesting feature, the tech and invention system is pretty Civ-like, while the diplomacy model is alright. The military aspect could use some attention in victoria 3, as it's somewhat generic and bland. Overall, this is a great game with a community that still remains active and a lot of mods available at the Paradox forums. I've put more than 100 hours into the game, and I can't wait for victoria 3!

So, in terms of a video game, I'd say 4 out of 5 stars. In terms of a paradox grand strategy game, I'd say 2 out of 5 stars.
This is a 4x grand strategy game set in the victorian era that takes place from 1835 to 1935. While it's historically accurate, it does leave out most of the african tribes in west africa, and it oversimplifies diplomacy.
If you've never played a paradox game before, I'd recommend it since it's a fine game, but I personally would recommend playing a different paradox strategy game, since they've got much better games. Personally I would recommend Europa universalis IV, and imperator rome instead of this game. It is a nice change of pace from those two, but It's not as well refined. 

The good.
This game has the best economy I have ever seen in any game. 5 out of 5 stars.
I like the technology system. 4 out of 5 stars
The diplomacy is simple and easy to use. 3 out of 5 stars since this is also a frustration to me.
The production of units is based on actual economic cost. No matter how much money you have if you don't have any rifles you can't recruit new infantry battallions 5 out 5 on unit recruitment.
The way your government interacts with the economy is dynamic depending on what type of government you have 5 out of 5. As france, I used laisez faire economics, so my economy managed itself.

The Bad.
Using the influence mechanics countries arbitrarily control other countries just because they are one of the top 8 countries in the world. The ninth country has influence over other countries in this fashion until he becomes the 8th, then suddenly he has the same as the number 1 country. While the system is cool, it's jarring, and I think it done the wrong way. Countries have no opinion change based on what is actually happening, their opinion of you is solely based on if you are one of the top 8 countries, and then if you are controlling them, or being discredited by the other powers. Because of this AI's almost never form truces with each other unless they are the top 8, and the minor nations are meaningless except as nuisances and pawns.
2 out of 5
The population growth is lacking. Yes people die in wars, but the population growth rates in game are based off the population growth rates of developed countries in the 21st century. Growth rates that are just barely above the replacement rate. Back in the 19th century, as many as 50% of people wouldn't live to see adulthood in some places, but the average family would have 6-8 kids(including stillborns and miscarraiges in both numbers), so you still get the population increasing by 50% every 40-50 years. The main reasons the population didn't stick to what it'd been was medicin and industry advancements, but like France went from maybe 10-20 million to almost 60 million in 100 years, and germany went from about that many to 100 million in germany.(not austria)(note that as many as 70% of the estimated 9-15 million germans in northern germany died in the 30 years war). So, while this mechanic has the potential for 5 out of 5 stars, due to the growth rate before researching any tech being about a 0.0 % growth rate, and the growth rates after researching medicinal techs being as low as 0.02, and 0.04, this mechanic actually becomes a bit of a hindrance when considering how their economy works, so I give it 2 out of 5 stars, but admit with a little polishing it can achieve more.
Great Britain is as powerful as he historically was and unrivaled in power and a bully. 3 out of 5.
The revolt mechanics only allow you to deal with a revolt after they rebel, and they will keep arbitrarily gathering armies after they reach 100% rebellion chance for up to 5 years, and you're powerless to do anything to stop it once revolt chance hits 100% even as the number of soldiers they're going to field goes up from 150,000 to 6,000,000 of my 14 million citizens. It's frustrating cause in other paradox strategy games I can try to prevent rebellions, and even if I don't their strength doesn't just keep arbitrarily going up untill every citizen in my country is now a soldier in the rebellion. Instead when the rebellion chance reaches 100% they rise up, and I can send my armies in. I honestly think this mechanic is the one that breaks the game, and it just makes me mad, cause if they fixed this, I'd honestly change my recommendation, and recommend you get the game. 1 out of 5 stars.
So war exhaustion is a thing, and it makes sense, an army is coming and burning cities, parents get tired of sending their sons to die in wars, that makes sense, but that's not the main driving force in war exhuastion in this game, if it was I'd say 5 out of 5 stars. But no, the main way of getting war exhuastion is peace offers. You see, you might get 1 or 2 war exhuastion a month if enemy armies occupy 5 of your 150 provinces, which makes sense, but as soon as they get 3-4% advantage in the war, they have enough war score to ask for a small demand, and so they do, about twice a month. This normally wouldn't be a problem, but if the enemy is winning the war, even if just by 3-4 percent, and they offer a peace treaty, and you reject, then the player gets 5 war exhuastion, and 1 global militancy, and this can happen every 20-25 days. (keep in mind militancy is what makes your pops rebel, so having 3-4 militancy in a province will spark a rebellion.) So in my campaign, I was at war with england, the most powerful country in the world, and I was winning, I had just invaded london (succesfully) when what do you know prussia declares war on me (france) and invades my territories. I immediately sign a peace treaty, but before I can bring my troops home, they've occupied 4-5 provinces, in the next 8 months, I get 8 war exhuastion from having provinces occupied, bring my war exhuastion from 36 to 44, and I get 40 war exhuastion from 8 offers of surrender, at this point, I've started occupying prussian land, I've destroyed all of the ottomans troops(they were a cobeligerent), but despite having overwhealming force, and a string of victories in every battle, my people are defeated and rebelling, simply because I didn't immediately agree to surrender. If this mechanic hadn't existed, I could've easily annexed all of the ottomans land in africa, and taken some land from prussia too, but because I lost a couple territories in the 2 months it took me to get my 100k troops home from england, and reinforce the damaged regiments, I had to reject 8 offers of surrender in that time, and now I've got a revolt of 14 million frenchmen out of population of 8 million that happens 2 months after the war. of these people unhappy with the government, they raise an army of 6 million soldiers. Yea, 6 million frenchmen overthrow the government, just because they didn't agree to surrender french land to prussia. Kinda not a thing that would happen ever. Imagine that imperial france defending against prussia and the ottomans in a war, and they win overwhelmingly, but 6 million frenchmen rise up as soldiers against the government just because they didn't accept surrender for 8 months during the 8 month war. There was a 0% percent chance that would've happened in the 19th century. Sorry paradox, bad play on that mechanic there..  so this mechanic is a 0 out of 5 stars, and it's the other reason I can't stand this game right now.

TLDR 
2 out of 5 stars.
Reasons to play.
Amazing economy. Your government plays differently depending on what it is, and that effects how you use the economy too!
The tech system is decent.
Reasons not to get it.
The revolt system suchs.
IF you reject an AI peace offer, your citizens will revolt as in you'll get an army to fight that has 50% of your population in it, and all of your native origin armies will defect to the revolution, just because you rejected an AI peace offer. 
So, I don't recommend because the flaws kind of ruin the good parts, and cause your save to just become not playable anymore. 2 out of 5 stars.

Lost my life to this game

I refunded this game two times, thinking it was too complex and that I'd need a PhD to even be able to comprehend what was going on. 

This game is very, very bad at introducing itself to new player, I'll tell you that much lol.

However, once I caved and bought the game on sale a third time, I committed to it and now it's easily my favorite Paradox game. If you're looking for a robust socioeconomic simulation from Paradox that offers actually interesting simulation beyond just a surface level, this is the game you want. The population is dynamic and ever evolving, with population expanding in real time down to the individual citizen. These citizens have different roles which can change depending on the conditions they're in. These citizens consume resources, different depending on who they are, that also are individually tied to a global economic simulation.

While this game can be buggy, it offers a level of complexity in its simulation beyond any of the other paradox games. Because of the detailed population mechanics, the game feels a lot more alive to me than other Paradox games (CK is also good in this regard, but in a different way). The economy is also alive in a sense and can function on its own with only moderate input. The short timeframe is also to this game's benefit I feel, as it avoids the absolute slog that CK and EU4 can end up feeling like after centuries. A full 100 year game is still very long, though, make no mistake. Things move fast in the Victorian era. 

Overall just a really great grand strategy game, certainly one of the best in the genre (if not the best, but that's heavily debatable of course). Make sure you get the dlc, they're essential. Also check out the mods, some of them are really great and add some really good refinements to the base experience.

Its the most underrated Paradox game. It is the most difficult Paradox game to learn but (at least in my opinion) is the most fun.

I guess I have enough hours to leave a pretty thought out review now. All my time is on vanilla, mostly with DLCs, which some people will tell you means I should reevaluate my mental health, but you can probably take to mean the game is even more enjoyable with mods. I'll probably compare vicky to stellaris a lot, as they both fill the niche of easy paradox games in my opinion, and I'm fairly sure I've gotten about the same playtime on both.

I will start this off by being realistic - honestly, Vicky 2 probably isn't the best Paradox game in the world. That said, it takes 10 hours to really figure out, and maybe another 10 to REALLY figure out, meaning you can spend 930 hours actually playing. Contrast that with other paradox titles that are constantly updated and having added depth to keep older players interested despite making things ever more complex for newer players. I have something like 500 hours in EUIV and 270 in CK2, but didn't have the time to learn them when they came out, and struggle to catch up now, so most of that play time is really just screwing around and figuring out how to do things again before they all change. Most of Victoria *isnt* actually complicated, just opaque, but it's not hard to quickly realize you don't really need to understand how a lot of the actual mechanics operate, as long as you know how to work with them.

That's really 90% of what the appeal is. It feels and plays like a Paradox game, more so than another simple game like Stellaris, but you can pick up the basics really easily, and do well enough to take on the AI in most situations. Then it's a matter of if you want to play it more like an idle game, challenge yourself, or try something really new. It does this better than something like stellaris by dint of the entire game loop having a very different start. Vicky is pretty varied, much more like what you'll experience in other paradox titles, while stellaris is pretty consistently going to play like a straightforward 4x game. Obviously, you get far more for customization options than you do in Vicky (you can cheat those in to a degree), but the basic gameplay for at least the early portion won't vary.

Which brings us to the biggest downfall. The end game isn't always great, especially due to the various, but generally unchanging starting situations. If you play as France, you're gonna be the number one world power by the midgame, and will be able to crush everyone if you play actively and conventionally. The late game just makes that easier for you, while more modern games (stellaris) are built to throw new challenges towards you. You can invert this by playing weaker nations that really develop in the later game, but it does mean that, for most of them, your early game is either sitting around waiting for things to build up, or having to obsessively micromanage.

If you find you often restart games to try new things or whatever, this is 100% one for you. If you like the Victorian era and want something not too crazy to get into, also for you. If you want something really expansive and have the time and energy to really sit down and learn a complex grand strategy game, something like EUIV probably does have a lot more to offer as a whole, though you will also pay a lot more for it.

This game is really enjoyable for one so old. It's one of the few games available which cover the Nineteenth Century, which is a shame, since it's actually a very interesting period. Its strongest feature is its economic system, which is quite in-depth and dynamic (note that I play with the Pop Demand Mod, which greatly improves the economy, among many other things). The simulation of political reform and development is also very interesting, the tech and invention system is Civ-like, while the diplomacy model is alright. The military aspect could use some attention in any possible sequel, as it's a bit generic and bland. Overall, this is a very good game with a community which remains active and a lot of mods available at the Paradox forums. I've put a lot more hours into this than my profile reflects, having bought it originally on Gamersgate when it released, and I remain among those hoping devoutly for a sequel.

Today we rule Prussia. Tomorrow the WORLD!
Game is super fun. The amount of complexity is mind-blowing, but the more you play the more you'll understand how each aspect of the game works. Once you understand the tech trees, diplomacy, warfare, and budgeting then the rest of the game pretty much works out on its own. For example, prioritize literacy techs in the Culture tab if your literacy is low (for example Russia) or prioritize diplomatic influence techs under the Commerce tab if you need to add other countries to your sphere of influence ASAP (for example Prussia). There's so many intricacies found within the game that can make it a little frustrating, but the joy you'll get once you finish in 1st place and do some crazy stuff like forming Greater Germany or westernizing China or dismantling Prussia as Scandinavia will make it all worth it. Bottom line: buy the game but make sure to get both expansions as well (A House Divided and Heart of Darkness). Base game is not as good without the gameplay tweaks implemented by the expansions.

If Paradox was a car manufacturer, the vehicles they would produce would have been just a car frame with a driver´s seat, an engine starter button, and an engine that wouldn´t work very well. They would sell it at a normal car price and you would have to slowly pay for every other car part in order to end up with a functioning car after half a decade or so. 

This being their business model, it led me to wait several years before purchasing their product.

I am still in love with the original Victoria and it´s expansion Revolutions, but I also wanted a bit of a change. So I gave Victoria 2 a try. I love everything they´ve done, and how they´ve incorporated a lot of mods into a new whole. The map is better, the game behaves great, the engine is forgiving to modding errors and it doesn´t feel alien at all. What I don´t like is the missing population micromanagment options. You basically don´t control anything. You are allowed to make a wish, through  the "national focus" button and that's it. If you hated the micromanagment of the old Victoria, then this game is as simple as Europa Universalis, go for it!

There are many games which are called 'modern classics' Victoria 2 should be one of them, this game is over 10 years old with almost a cult community surrounding it, it is one of my favourite paradox games and I would recommend it [b] HOWEVER [/b] there are numerous bugs and glitches which you will have to be prepared for if you buy this game.

Here are some of the bugs which you may face:
	- There is no UI scaling so you can forget high DPI monitors (4K, 1440P), unless you like squinting
	- If you have two monitors you may have to turn one off otherwise a black bar will appear on the side of your screen, this might be another 4k issue.
	- Random crashes can happen so you may want to save frequently

I may also need to mention that this game really needs the DLCs, there is allot of content lost without the DLCs which you can of course expect from Paradox. Please do also note this isn't EU4, the DLC situation isn't as bad.

If your fine with playing a game were you have to read a tutorial on how to open it and what not to do I would suggest giving it a go.

ALSO DON'T ALT-TAB ON LAUNCH (It causes Vic2 to not open and you have to restart, as with most old games)

To save on having to explain a lot of the basics of the grand strategy genre, and what paradox games tend to be about, this review is for people who are familiar with and like those games, and might be wondering if Victoria II is a good pickup. 

This is a game that I absolutely love, and I've pumped hundreds of hours into. More than my steam numbers would show. I would go so far as to say it might be my all time favorite paradox game. There are so many things that are great about it. The detailed political system with parties, issues, reforms and election campaigns where your choices may or may not change outcomes. It has a challenging but rewarding diplomacy system based on spheres of influence which can be threatened at any point by existing rivals or emerging powers within the sphere. The military system, and the fact that soldiers are recruited from segments of the population, which don't necessarily regenerate at a set pace makes combat encounters uniquely intense and stressful for a grand strategy game; and after a few deadly battles you'll find yourself meticulously planning your fights for minimum casualties. The culture system in the game is also unique in that multiple cultures typically coexist inside a single province. The game more or less accurately models the diverse and amorphous patchwork of languages and nationalities found in different regions of the world. What's more is that unlike in more recent paradox titles like Imperator and CKIII, the rate of cultural change is quite realistically slow. Don't expect to fully assimilate the population of your nation over the short, 100 year timescale. To me, this really helps the 19th Century setting to feel more immersive.
That's not even touching on the colonization and economy systems, which could take up pages on their own, and are both quite deep and rewarding systems that might be the game's best selling point. 

As for more general stuff; the game runs alright, not great. It's very cpu intensive in the late game, and even on decent modern rigs it can chug. For a 10 year old game, that's not a good sign. If you have a lower end pc, your performance will be worse, but in my experience it's still playable, even on most laptops today.  
The UI and keybinds are surprisingly pretty good given how old it is. Rally points and shift clicking are very needed features that this game has. If you play a lot of CKIII, you might get frustrated at how few keyboard shortcuts there are; but once you get into the flow of things, it's really not that bad. 

So everything I've had to say so far has been either positive or neutral. Victoria II still holds up, and if you could get it at a decent price, I highly recommend it to all grand strategy fans.
The problem I have with this game is the cost. Getting this game which came out in 2010 and its DLC today will cost you $66. That's ridiculous. Just getting the two expansions and skipping the (Admittedly needless) cosmetic upgrades will still set you back $50. For comparison, Crusader kings III which came out last year and its single released content pack will cost you $59. So buying Victoria II today might very well cost more than Paradox' most recent game. 

Is it worth it though? Maybe. I mean I've put many hundreds of hours into it. But $60 for a game going on 11 years old is a huge turnoff for most people, and understandably so. That's a big investment for something that is not nearly as polished as other games in the same price-range. 

If it goes on sale, which it periodically does, I can fully recommend it; and if you find it somewhere else cheaper, I would also fully recommend it; but if the pricetag of $66 is too steep, that's understandable.
A complicated game, however, if you put the effort in to learn it's an amazingly fun, challenging and interesting game. Really hope they make Victoria III! :)

Reminds me of this quote.

In my younger and more vulnerable years my father gave me some advice that I’ve been turning over in my mind ever since.

“Whenever you feel like criticizing any one,” he told me, “just remember that all the people in this world haven’t had the advantages that you’ve had.”

He didn’t say any more, but we’ve always been unusually communicative in a reserved way, and I understood that he meant a great deal more than that. In consequence, I’m inclined to reserve all judgments, a habit that has opened up many curious natures to me and also made me the victim of not a few veteran bores. The abnormal mind is quick to detect and attach itself to this quality when it appears in a normal person, and so it came about that in college I was unjustly accused of being a politician, because I was privy to the secret griefs of wild, unknown men. Most of the confidences were unsought — frequently I have feigned sleep, preoccupation, or a hostile levity when I realized by some unmistakable sign that an intimate revelation was quivering on the horizon; for the intimate revelations of young men, or at least the terms in which they express them, are usually plagiaristic and marred by obvious suppressions. Reserving judgments is a matter of infinite hope. I am still a little afraid of missing something if I forget that, as my father snobbishly suggested, and I snobbishly repeat, a sense of the fundamental decencies is parcelled out unequally at birth.

And, after boasting this way of my tolerance, I come to the admission that it has a limit. Conduct may be founded on the hard rock or the wet marshes, but after a certain point I don’t care what it’s founded on. When I came back from the East last autumn I felt that I wanted the world to be in uniform and at a sort of moral attention forever; I wanted no more riotous excursions with privileged glimpses into the human heart. Only Gatsby, the man who gives his name to this book, was exempt from my reaction — Gatsby, who represented everything for which I have an unaffected scorn. If personality is an unbroken series of successful gestures, then there was something gorgeous about him, some heightened sensitivity to the promises of life, as if he were related to one of those intricate machines that register earthquakes ten thousand miles away. This responsiveness had nothing to do with that flabby impressionability which is dignified under the name of the “creative temperament.”– it was an extraordinary gift for hope, a romantic readiness such as I have never found in any other person and which it is not likely I shall ever find again. No — Gatsby turned out all right at the end; it is what preyed on Gatsby, what foul dust floated in the wake of his dreams that temporarily closed out my interest in the abortive sorrows and short-winded elations of men.

Best game ever.

I've played A LOT of Victoria 2 over the years, and I keep coming back to it because it offers a very unique experience in the world of grand strategy games. While the combat systems leave something to be desired, as most of the important war decisions are made before it starts, the golden goose of this game is its economy and pops system. Every single good that is produced in the game is tracked from its seller to its buyer, and every single person on the planet has things they want to buy and money to spend on it. This is a game where I am able to start literal world wars over petty border disputes, and I am often more interested in watching my factories buzz along because its just that interesting to nudge them in the right direction.

And I do mean every pop, this is not some Stellaris style game where millions of people are represented as a single unit. While the game does group demographics together, they are split into incredibly distinct categories and have an exact number of people in them. The nationality, religion, profession and location of your pops all end up contributing to how it interacts with your wider nation, and it feels incredibly complex without becoming completely obscure. the 10,000 Catholic-Irish craftsmen who have immigrated to Boston may not cause much of a stink for Uncle Sam, but the several million Koreans in occupied Japanese territory certainly will make the Emperor have a bad migraine if he's not careful. No other game I have ever played can simulate an actual economic crash or a politically motivated rebellion (or some combination of the two as is often the case) in an emergent way like Victoria 2 does. 

The major downside is that as an older Paradox title, it can have trouble running on newer devices, and mod support is non existent, and if you enjoy it enough to play it like I do, you are going to want to mod it. However, there are plenty of good instructional videos on how to go about this, and anyone who is familiar with doing more manual modding processes probably wont have to much issue with the steam version.

Overall, I highly recommend this to anyone who enjoys Paradox style grand strategies, but is looking for something a little different than their usual fare.

I've only played 5 games and I have almost 200 hours. I'll outline my first 3 experiences in the game below:

In my first game as the US, I got invaded by the British twice, lost most of New England to them, and then had to deal with over 20 years of constant civil war/revolution after the official "Civil War" due to the instability of losing two massive fully mobilized wars. Eventually, I ended up as a socialist US, and finally won back the territory stolen from me 60 years before. 

In my second game, I played as Russia. I achieved a 90% literacy rate by the middle of the 19th century, invaded Manchuria, lost 30% literacy, and had to go to war with a British/Chinese alliance. Also formed the USSR about 30 years earlier than historically reasonable and burned down Eastern Germany around 3 times. 

In my third game, I played as Brazil. For a while, I roamed free in South America, accidentally invaded a nation in the US Sphere of Influence, and then waged a successful 4 year guerrilla war in the Amazon against the US and their allies, eventually succeeding in getting Panama or whatever Central American country I attempted to get a chunk of land from.

This is the most interesting historical grand strategy I've ever played. Simply by playing things out (and not reverting to an old save because one bad thing happens), so much fun stuff can happen. I have a hard time getting into any of Paradox's other grand strategy games because none of them are quite like this.

While you're here, here's a recipe for chocolate chip cookies:
Equipment Needed:
Measuring Spoons
Measuring Cups
KitchenAid Mixer
Spatula
Baking Sheet

Ingredients Needed
1 cup salted butter* softened
1 cup white (granulated) sugar
1 cup light brown sugar packed
2 tsp pure vanilla extract
2 large eggs
3 cups all-purpose flour
1 tsp baking soda
½ tsp baking powder
1 tsp sea salt***
2 cups chocolate chips (or chunks, or chopped chocolate)

Instructions:
Preheat oven to 375 degrees F.
Line a baking pan with parchment paper and set aside.
In a separate bowl mix flour, baking soda, salt, baking powder.
Mix cream together butter and sugars until combined.
Beat in eggs and vanilla until fluffy.
Mix in the dry ingredients until combined.
Add 12 oz package of chocolate chips and mix well.
Roll 2-3 TBS (depending on how large you like your cookies) of dough at a time into balls and place them evenly spaced on your prepared cookie sheets. (alternately, use a small cookie scoop to make your cookies).
Bake in preheated oven for approximately 8-10 minutes.
Take them out when they are just BARELY starting to turn brown.
Let them sit on the baking pan for 2 minutes before removing to cooling rack.
Enjoy!

[b]Under the hood, Paradox's most impressive game[/b]

Compared to Paradox’s other grand strategy games, especially Europa Universalis and Hearts of Iron, Victoria II seems at first to be the ugly, obtuse, and obsolescent abandoned stepchild of the family and while I would argue that the even more obscure March of the Eagles fits this title more, Vicky is all of those things. Despite this, this game continues to host an avid fanbase and modding community, because there is no other grand strategy game in existence that attempts to cover the rapid and complex political, technological, economic, and military developments of the 19th and early 20th centuries as well as Victoria II does. With one set starting date, Vicky lacks the variety of EUIV and CK2, but each country faces a specific crafted scenario of events and political circumstances that render most countries uniquely engaging experiences with their own specific goals and ambitions. The diplomatic system represents the time well, featuring mechanics that rank and empower your nation to influence other nations and colonize based on its global clout, while the military combat system, albeit basic compared to the rest of the game, represents the advancements of the time well. It doesn’t hurt that the music is great too.

However, the core of Victoria II’s unique appeal is the mind-boggling complexity of its simulated global socioeconomic system, which represents the production, consumption, class, nationality, religion, and political opinion of every individual male worker in the entire world, whose collective activities and status all feed into systems of local, national, and international commercial exchange, manufacturing, migration, and politics, which are all under the influence of various national political and economic pressures from events, changes, and government actions across the world. This level of interlocking complexity lends Victoria II a level of socioeconomic simulation unparalleled in any other grand strategy game of its scope. This is not necessarily always a good thing, as even hundreds of hours into the game, much of this system and its various tendencies and idiosyncrasies seem forever unknowable in a game almost entirely composed of data tables and pie charts overlaid onto a map, but if such an intricate system interests you, Victoria II could be worth the money. The learning curve may seem insurmountably steep at first, but if you can get a grip on the basics, an unparalleled grand strategy exploration of one of the most transformative centuries of human history awaits.

Ever feel like you missed out on the scramble for Africa? Have you wanted to send millions of men to die in WWI? Have you ever wanted your nation to crumble under crippling economic sanctions? Then this is the game for you!

In all seriousness Victoria 2 is one of the best paradox games out there. Although it has it's problems, and is dated in many ways, it still holds up as a solid grand strategy game.

Pros:
1. Pops. The Pop system makes this game truly awesome and gives each nation a unique feel. Pops represent your actual population and their statistics determine how your nation functions. For example, a nation such as the UK has high literacy and a well established industrial base, which allows for faster industrialization, whereas a country like Columbia has a relatively low literacy and poorly established industry, which makes the early game about educating and establishing industry, which gives it a much different feel than the UK. It also gives each nation a concrete way to tell how well off a nation is, which differs from games like Hoi4 where each nation has similar levels of development or EU4 which can sometimes feel like just stacking modifiers.
2. Conquest. Both EU4 and HOI4, for as great as they are, feel very much like map painting. Vic2, however, discourages map painting, and instead offers alternative methods such as sphereing, which prevents conflicts over regions from escalating to full scale war at points. Additionally, units take up real pops, so fighting a large war can cost you much of your army, which taps into your real population, aka wars cause you to lose pops which requires you to spend time at peace to recover from wars.
3. Economy. The economy in Vic2 feels realistic and encourages the acquisition of new sources of RGOs, or Resource Gathering Operations. This enourages things like building a large sphere, or in cases of non world powers, specializing your industry to fit the resources available to you. This can make different nations follow different paths of conquest. For example, a nation like the USA has an abundance of RGO to build industry, whereas nations like Japan will have to expand to get what they want, making each nations economic situation unique. Additionally, the fact that goods are sold on an open market makes things like wars have massive effects on world trade.

There are numerous other pros, such as modability.

Cons:
1. UI. The UI feel really dated, and fails to notify you of many things. For example, countries will break alliances, and you can only see that in a little area on your screen, so you often miss important information. Additionally, I feel the game should better notify you of major changes like shifting great power alliances.
2. Rebels. They are crazy. Like I get that you have to keep your population happy, but I should not be having nationwide revolts as a stable nation cause my pops dont have a bit of wool. There are ways to fix this, but it can still be a problem.

However, the pro far outweigh the cons. A couple suggestions however:
1. GET. ALL. DLC. Seriously get all the dlc and the game on sale. You dont need all the unit packs, just Heart of Darkness and House divided. Most mods require both.
2. Start with vanilla, but I recommend switching to HPM soon. HPM is kinda like Vanilla+ and adds a lot more historical content while still keeping it vanilla like.

Overall, great buy!

[ Victoria II – Review ]
This public administration simulator has hit a sweet spot. It is not a game about warfare. It is about education, science, commerce, industry, diplomacy, social reform, political stability... and warfare!

Victoria II's high complexity does not confuse the player at all – so long as (s)he has dedicated about one hour to studying the game's basic mechanics. It hard to master, but very rewarding.

The game is accessible because it *makes sense*. It is, in fact, quite realistic. If during a crisis you ask yourself, "Would this make sense in real life?", it is probably somehow implemented in the game.

Two unrealistic aspects have come under my radar. First, resources are not so realistically allocated; for instance, there is neither iron nor petroleum in Brazil. Second, Victoria II's economics promotes state-governed industrialization as the only efficient option, but it is a policy which has had mixed results in history.

The game is very appropriate for history and geopolitics fans. It plays more like a simulator than a game, as someone has once said to me.

—

[ Victoria II – My Campaigns]
The campaigns always begin in 1836, at least without the DLC, and I always choose to be in charge of the recently independent Empire of Brazil. I intend to master the administration of Brazil.

My first campaign aimed, very naively, at scientific and educational glory. This was at the expense of industrialism and militarism, resulting in a weak Empire that saw external agents effortlessly dominating its territory. The UK dominated our Northeastern region, Venezuela tookup the Brazilian Amazonas,  and Argentina almost annexed Rio Grande do Sul!

My second campaign was much more professional, exploiting production, trade, and industry so as to enrich my population and enlist a great army. Alas, after great industrial effort, I found out that my country produced neither coal nor iron. There weren't any available for me in the scarce international market either. My industry therefore had little to no raw material. The Empire owned monstrous factories within which there were no supplies to be seen!!

My third campaign saw me learn how to efficiently colonize regions containing coal and iron, including most of my South American neighbors and extending to sub-Saharan Africa. Raw materials in abundance would solve all my industrial problems, I thought.

The sad result was that, although I became a country with huge factories containing massive raw material surpluses, my country had very little qualified workers – about 5% of what I needed. Ugh. Traumatized from my tragic first campaign, my current administration had neglected teachers, intellectuals, and corporate executives. Their absence prevented me from developing a skilled workforce.

I failed.

—

[Victoria II – Future Developments]
Time for my fourth campaign. I am now back to the drawing board, studying population growth and workforce development.

My most recent insight is that colonization might not be the best strategy. Perhaps – perhaps! – I can use my diplomatic influence to gain pacific access to world markets (thus buying coal and iron). I might even be able to build factories in other countries, using their own coal and iron (and sulphur and petroleum). Hopefully such an economic agreement would be beneficial to both me and my colleague country, but what really matters is that it would be good for me! 😊

The diplomatic plan above would make sense in real life. Would such strategy make sense in the game? The fun part is: I don't know. Let's find out.

NOTE: THIS REVIEW ONLY APPLIES TO VICTORIA 2 WITH THE "HEART OF DARKNESS" AND "A HOUSE DIVIDED" EXPANSIONS. I have not played the base game, nor do I intend to, as many online have derided it in favor of the final version. I also am not using the HPM, or any mods for that matter.

I finally got above 1000 hrs. in Civ 5 and decided that I needed to try a more in-depth grand strategy game, especially one with historical elements, which I prefer over sci-fi, fantasy, etc. I had never played a Paradox title, regrettably, and the online consensus seemed to be that Vic. 2 was the deepest for tall play and EUIV for wide. I went for the former as I am just better at and more experienced with the building/management aspects of strategy games than I am the war/expansion aspects (though I am learning, thanks to Bannerlord and Three Kingdoms, my first titles in each of those series).  Victoria 2 is so far the most immersive strategy game I have played. 

I am using "immersive" here to describe both the setting/narrative and the gameplay itself. By playing this game, I am learning so much about a period of history I generally ignore (usually go for like classical or medieval stuff) and satisfying my general interest in geopolitics and learning how the world works (in a simplified model). Every person in the world is simulated from 1836-1936. Their needs, wants, ideological sympathies, ethnic/religious loyalties, etc. all factor in to global politics and economics in a real way. Stop looking for action games where your choices have an effect on the world. This is almost an RPG.

I hate to compare a Paradox game to Civ 5. Civ is turn-based and is a 4X that doesn't simulate history, but it is my best reference. The mechanics in Civ 5 are significantly easier to understand and its streamlined design enables playing "optimally" (with the assistance of ZigZagAl, Car'ls Civ Guides, and FilthyRobot of course). However, approaching your first Civ games without knowledge of the mechanics, but with good political/economic intuition, will not lead to success outside of the lower difficulties. 

I have a degree in economics, yet no matter how many hours I play or wiki articles I read, I will never fully understand Victoria 2. However, my first game turned out very successful. "Success" is subjective here since Civ 5 has victory conditions and Vic. 2 is more of a simulation, but I was able to achieve Great Power status with a country that started as a Secondary Power, which I'll consider a success. A lot of that success can be attributed to just general knowledge of history and role-playing.

Since I had far more success using intuition in my first Vicky game than I did in my first Civ games, I would say that Victoria 2 is a more intuitive game for a certain type of gamer. This gamer has to be interested in history and willing to invest time and mental energy into learning a complex game (i.e. not a casual). If a friend of mine who was new to grand strategy and met those conditions wanted a recommendation for a new game, I would suggest Victoria 2 over Civ 5. Though, I am relatively new to strategy games myself, and would probably recommend an "easier" (totally subjective) game once I have more experience with Paradox, Total War, or any of the other amazing strategy games I never played because I was addicted to Civ 5.

Best Paradox game by far. It has tanks, planes, and automobiles. It has armies, muskets, and machine guns! What more could one want? It's economy system is one of the most complex, and in depth systems created by Paradox. The combat will not be hard for EU4, or Imperator players to learn. The game has a great sound track, and is by far the most memorable Paradox soundtrack yet, and it fits the theme perfectly. You can play Prussia, Sweden, Russia, Austria, France, The United Kingdom, the USA,  Mexico, Colombia, the USCA, China, Japan, and many other countries, and all maintain their own unique feel, even though this game predates Mission Trees, or Focus trees. Great game!

This is a seriously underrated game, and it is one of my favorite Paradox selections ever.

First off, however, I will start with the cons.

1. The combat system isn't great. By late game, having dozens of armies and fleets and micromanaging large fronts are just too overwhelming, and this is easily my least favorite part of the game.
2. The learning curve. It took me months to learn how to play well, and the tutorials (while better than in most Paradox selections) still weren't adequate.
3. To really enjoy the full experience, you NEED both of the DLC.
4. There are an insane number of popups. When you are running a small country and want to speed the game up when you have no options left to do, popups every three seconds will pause your game until you read and close them, slowing you down dramatically.

Now, the pros:
1. The political system is really intriguing, and has more depth than any other grand strategy game I have ever played.
2. The economic and factory system is fairly balanced and leaves the player with a number of options to purse (state capitalism and laissez faire, for example)
3. Replayability: there are a large number of countries to choose from, including ones like Scotland and Ireland, with different challenges, populations, technologies, and resources. There are quite a few decent mods out there that will allow you to get a different experience every time.

Overall, I would say this is one of my favorite Paradox games. The DLC is overpriced, but they are often on sale. I would definitely recommend this game
