Victoria II, 3 hours in:
"This game is terrible. The UI is unreadable, and I have no idea what all these numbers mean."

Victoria II, 100 hours in:
"I will now proceed to add China to my sphere of influence. This will crash the world economy in less than five seconds and prepare me well for my invasion of the German Empire."

Ever feel like you missed out on the scramble for Africa? Have you wanted to send millions of men to die in WWI? Have you ever wanted your nation to crumble under crippling economic sanctions? Then this is the game for you!

In all seriousness Victoria 2 is one of the best paradox games out there. Although it has it's problems, and is dated in many ways, it still holds up as a solid grand strategy game.

Pros:
1. Pops. The Pop system makes this game truly awesome and gives each nation a unique feel. Pops represent your actual population and their statistics determine how your nation functions. For example, a nation such as the UK has high literacy and a well established industrial base, which allows for faster industrialization, whereas a country like Columbia has a relatively low literacy and poorly established industry, which makes the early game about educating and establishing industry, which gives it a much different feel than the UK. It also gives each nation a concrete way to tell how well off a nation is, which differs from games like Hoi4 where each nation has similar levels of development or EU4 which can sometimes feel like just stacking modifiers.
2. Conquest. Both EU4 and HOI4, for as great as they are, feel very much like map painting. Vic2, however, discourages map painting, and instead offers alternative methods such as sphereing, which prevents conflicts over regions from escalating to full scale war at points. Additionally, units take up real pops, so fighting a large war can cost you much of your army, which taps into your real population, aka wars cause you to lose pops which requires you to spend time at peace to recover from wars.
3. Economy. The economy in Vic2 feels realistic and encourages the acquisition of new sources of RGOs, or Resource Gathering Operations. This enourages things like building a large sphere, or in cases of non world powers, specializing your industry to fit the resources available to you. This can make different nations follow different paths of conquest. For example, a nation like the USA has an abundance of RGO to build industry, whereas nations like Japan will have to expand to get what they want, making each nations economic situation unique. Additionally, the fact that goods are sold on an open market makes things like wars have massive effects on world trade.

There are numerous other pros, such as modability.

Cons:
1. UI. The UI feel really dated, and fails to notify you of many things. For example, countries will break alliances, and you can only see that in a little area on your screen, so you often miss important information. Additionally, I feel the game should better notify you of major changes like shifting great power alliances.
2. Rebels. They are crazy. Like I get that you have to keep your population happy, but I should not be having nationwide revolts as a stable nation cause my pops dont have a bit of wool. There are ways to fix this, but it can still be a problem.

However, the pro far outweigh the cons. A couple suggestions however:
1. GET. ALL. DLC. Seriously get all the dlc and the game on sale. You dont need all the unit packs, just Heart of Darkness and House divided. Most mods require both.
2. Start with vanilla, but I recommend switching to HPM soon. HPM is kinda like Vanilla+ and adds a lot more historical content while still keeping it vanilla like.

Overall, great buy!

What is there to be said about Victoria 2? Above all, it is unique, both in the framework of the Paradox GSGs and games in general.

Part of this stems from the procedural nature and dynamic granularity of its systems. Everything in the game, be it tax income and the tides of political movements to industrial development and the potential size of one's army, is based on POPs - units of population that equate roughly to a family of four people. Each POP has needs, opinions, political leanings, a profession, and the ability to move between locations in the world. A product of POP actions (such as their purchasing habits, their jobs, and their quantity) is the RGO and resource system, with the world market and its macroeconomics being incredibly integral to gameplay. Powerful players in the world market can grow rich off trade and starve their enemies of ammunition or industrial goods, while growth is challenging for small, resource-poor nations competing with large producers.

Another part of this stems from the simple fact that this game is old and incredibly janky. The economic system, while quite deep, is built off some very flawed roots and is incredibly unrealistic (there's a joke about artisans being able to make tanks out of fruit under the proper conditions). Wars are to a degree predicated based on RNG due to the way Infamy is acquired (and the need for certain popularities of Jingoism in order to fabricate additional wargoals while already at war); under the right conditions, annexing the Rhineland as France can cause no international controversy while annexing a tiny German state can bring on a Napoleonic-level coalition. On the other side of things, there's no distinction between "ironman" gameplay and the use of the debug console or savescumming, and the game is rife with exploits. Finally, the game really needs both of its DLC expansions in order to function properly; thankfully, these are obscenely cheap. 

Altogether the game is highly flawed, but highly satisfying for the fact that it feels living. Both the POP system and the economy are dynamic and always changing, making growth satisfying and meaning that revolutions and large wars can impact the entire world. The game truly flourishes with modifications, however, which do many things from making Africa far more fleshed out to introducing even more alternate history pathways for the world to develop along.

On the whole, I would highly recommend playing this game, though with the caveat that it's not perfect and takes a long time (and a lot of trial and error) to really learn.

While this game is fun, it doesn't allow you to annex other countries or puppet them. It instead a slow burn where you try to expand your economy while hurting other economies. I vastly prefer Hearts of Iron IV because it allows you to snowball your economy. If world conquests doesn't sound like much fun, but smaller and more frequent wars do then I highly recommend this game.

From justified racism to announcing the creation of Israel, cultural genocide to realpolitik concerning whether or not tens of millions of young men should die in a great war over a few thousand sheep herders in the Sahara, Victoria II is *the* 19th century simulator. Learn the joys of exploitative colonialism as you learn the wants and needs of the most in depth market system there's ever been in a strategy game. Emulate Napoleon as you crush coalition after coalition sent to destroy you because you went barely over the infamy limit, a fate punishable by intense flogging. Then after that, become conditioned into nutting the second you see the words "Can use Gas Attack" as you use the Geneva Convention to clean yourself up.

The only legitimately good or even playable Paradox game honestly, and that is with mods, Even for all its flaws, and despite my ever-stronger hate for PDX, I kinda hold a special place for Vic2. Imperialism Simulator basically.

Obviously this game is in great need for some updates (hopefully in the form of an HD and largely-reworked Vic3?), but the more in-depth focus on ideologies, industrialisation, global markets, reforms and more (in comparison to other Paradox games) often provide some much needed flavour for what can be a pretty long game. I mean, playing as Siam is ok, but playing as global industrial powerhouse and communist dictatorship Siam just adds that little extra pinch of interesting to your game, at least I think so. Plus, the era has some pretty interesting and/or greatly historically significant events, such as the American Civil War, WW1, the Great Depression, the Scramble for Africa, the rise of Germany and Italy, the fall of Austria, the invention of Communism and Fascism, etc... Plus, it's probably the cheapest Paradox mapping game, so maybe the best to start off with.

Victoria 2 is, in my opinion, the most underrated of the Paradox grand strategy pantheon.

Something about this game and it's 19th century setting just agrees with me immensely. The political intrigue, the empire building and colonization, the struggle of world powers on a grand stage. The birth and death of Romanticism, and great strides in military and naval technology.  The fantastic soundtrack also helps to immerse you in the experience, an underrated element of Paradox games.

No playthrough is exactly the same. One game as Prussia may go entirely different from the next one. You can take the Ottoman Empire and turn it into a powerhouse, or prevent Russia's monarchy from collapsing. My most fond memory is playing as Sokoto and forming a vast West African empire. One that can even stem the tide of European colonization. Or taking Qing China and modernizing it and expanding across Asia and the Pacific Ocean.

As for gripes and issues, I find this game can crash very easily, so I highly recommend saving often. But my biggest issue is just the hassle of starting a multiplayer with friends. Having to get on the same checksum can bet troubling at times, and the stability of multiplayer games can vary wildly. I recommend not having more than a handful of player per game.

Overall, it's a fantastic game, and I just really want them to make a Victoria 3 already!

There are lots of government forms, ideologies and reforms, there's an in-depth trade, the diplomacy, overall, is enjoyable and there are several features which make your world be alive, like the women rights, the education and the healthcare, Victoria II is not a Total War game and I love it because of that. The year be 1836 and the technological turning point of history is at hand. As a simulator of Victorian political-economy, it's up to you to oversee the demographic transition of farmers and simple townsfolk to urban-industrial wageslaves, with bare minimum compensation and all sorts of health hazards, at a global scale. Technological and economic progress must be slowed by nothing, not even human degradation, such is the lesson we have learned from the Enlightenment. Thus, you have two choices: join the Forces of Progress, whether liberal capitalist or Marxist, and push mankind on towards its ultimate destiny of economic finality, whatever that may be, or keep standing amongst the ruins of the Old World as a fascist or reactionary, clinging to what little remains of the true spirit of the Ancien Régimes of Antiquity and the Middle Ages. Anyone who clings to the idea of "conservatism" should be prepared to be swept away in the current of Progress; the train stops only for those who are willing to apply the brakes and suffer the jerk of a sudden stop.

This game is probably the best strategy game I've ever played. Sure it's flawed and could really use a sequel, (Which will probably release five seconds before the sun consumes earth) but it still is a masterpiece. I'm going to describe each of the four main elements of this game in their own section, so here we go.                                      

This game has probably is one of the most deep economic simulators out there. You constantly find yourself looking at the trade tab seeing what product prices are rising and which are plummeting. doing the math on what goods would be profitable to produce. and making sure you stockpile military equipment should war strike your nation. and although it can get a bit micromanagey at times it is still quite fun.

Combat is relatively basic for most of the game (until tanks and planes are introduced) with one basic formation of armies. That being infantry in the front, artillery in the back, and cavalry and engineers to support them. The main key here is the battle dice, a semi-random way to determine the outcome of battles.
While to some extent they are random different things affect your rolls such as what general you have, terrain, and whether or not you can use gas attack. The navy is even simpler with terrain being completely removed from the question. All in all i'd say it's incredibly satisfying and quite fun.

Diplomacy is relatively simple for minor nations (basically revolving around which great power you want to ally), but once you become a great power and influence and colonialism are introduced, it becomes very interesting. You end up arguing with other great powers that Switzerland should be in your sphere of influence and not theirs, or that this territory should be under my control. It creates really interesting diplomatic scenarios which are even better in multiplayer.

The final aspect i want to talk about is expansion. Expansion is relatively hard to do (as other great powers don't really like you breaching the peace) unless one of three things are true. 1: the nation you are trying to attack has a territory which is a core of your nation (you obtain cores by scripted events or having a majority of your nation's ethnicity in that province). 2: The nation you are attacking is primitive or uncivilized or 3: The province is unoccupied an can be colonized (colonization mainly kicks off during the scramble for Africa).  As for wars, ideology, and revolution the game is significantly less scripted than other games such as Hearts of Iron, which is really refreshing and makes each game feel different. All in all I'd say this aspect is amazing

To conclude, this game is amazing and for $45 bucks with dlc (which you'll need) it's pretty fairly priced. I would certainly recommend this game to any strategy fan. P.S. I would highly recommend getting the historical project mod as it adds so much to the game :)

[h1]Victoria II - The Best Paradox Grand Strategy Game[/h1]

[b]Victoria II[/b] is a [i]grand strategy game[/i], developed by [b]Paradox Development Studio[/b], who are also known for series such as [i]Hearts of Iron[/i] or [i]Europa Universalis[/i]. Similar to those series, in Victoria II, the player gets to play any country in the world in 1836, or (with "[b]A House Divided[/b]") 1861. While playing the desired country, one has to gain [i]prestige[/i], [i]industrial power[/i], and [i]military power[/i] to be able to compete in the everlasting arms race for power in the world.
The year of release is 2010, but the game still enjoys popularity nowadays - Why is that?

What distinguishes Victoria II from other Paradox grand strategy titles is the high focus on [b]industrial and political management[/b]. The game has a built-in population simulation with groups that share origin, work, belief and location (POPs). This feature gives every [strike]person[/strike] adult male on the planet their own story!
This creates realism and depth in many ways.
For example, the [i]POPs[/i] have different jobs, allowing for a working economy which the player has to manage - or put the liberals in charge and hope that they will. This economy has the important task of providing the population with what it needs and no game manages to recreate this system as good as Victoria II does.
Since the game lasts until the end of 1935, a lot of political changes and new ideologies got written down for the history books. The prime example for that is the rise of social democracy and socialism, sadly a bit confusingly named in this game, with [i]socialists[/i] basically being social democrats, and [i]communists[/i] being socialists. The change in political issues during the years make for a shift in party popularity over time. These parties have their own political goals like [i]military[/i] or [i]economical[/i] policies which change what the player can do. Because of that, the player can influence the election results by giving statements during the campaign, in reference to political issues. In spite of that, the player sometimes has to let democracy rule and [b][strike]have the annoying liberals destroy the factories[/strike][/b] let their country run its own cause.
The military part is obviously also included, though not as sophisticated as in Hearts of Iron games. In my humble opinion, the politics are even more important in a game set in this era, which is why I think that Victoria II is indeed [b]The Best Paradox Grand Strategy Game[/b].

Where to begin with this Paradox Interactive classic?

It's the single greatest media representation of the entirety of the Victorian era and beyond, with great power geopolitics through the form of spheres of influence, an infamy system, and colonization. It displays the industrialization of the west and the ever increasing technological disparity of the world throughout the 19th and 20th centuries. Its warfare systems and mechanics are quite damning but can be mastered by the most daring grand strategist; combat in this age heavily emphasizes the exponentially expanding killing power of weapons and armaments during this period, thus defensive terrain, technology, and a decent commander will always dictate upon the battlefield (that, and raw numbers: less you be the Qing).

There is so much that one could say about this games, especially when one factors in all of highly dedicated modification projects which have no doubt extended the timeline of this game to the point where many still love and play this aged game into 2021. There is and will never be anything that can compare to Victoria 2, she is a once in a lifetime game that even the current devs at Paradox can barely understand.

I would not recommend this game without the DLC that being said if you like strategy games which feature copious amounts of historical and economic accuracy this is the game for you. My only critique is that the communist governments are undemocratic whereas the definition of the Dictatorship of the Proletarian is a system in which the workers democratically own and control not just the means of production but the state as well. Also you can't have freedom of press??? and you can bring back slavery as a communist government? Like chattel slavery? Damn well nothing that can't be fixed in a mod or two. I get if you want to have the antagonists of your game be Stalinists but just don't give the fascist faction freedom of speech and aspects of democracy whereas the opposite side of the spectrum is a literal dictatorship. 
I love a game where you can play as the Texan Republic that absorbs parts of Mexico and the concept of Brazil becoming a world power. This game is not as fast pace as HOI4 and needs a little bit more strategy than Blitzkrieg. Make sure to look up a few youtube videos on the subject. Overall rating is an 8/10 with some minor suggestions and criticisms. If you really don't like the game when you get it there are a few mods which are pretty cool such as the Cold War mod.

If you love really getting to grips with a VERY complicated game system, this game is perfect for you.
If you can giggle at Communist United States and Fascist Australia, this game is also perfect for you.
If you like Paradox and wanna do megacampaigns, this game is ultra-perfect for you. Fascist Kievan Rus? Perfection.

If you have played CK2/3 or EU4 and thought "Nice, but what if combat made more sense and the economy was far more complicated?" then sign yourself right up for Vic2, 'cos in no other Paradox game will you get the thrill of building a sweet Fabric Factory in Wales.

Likewise, if you have played HOI4 and thought "Nice, but what if the whole game wasn't entirely based around economy fuelling the military but rather a generous mix of the two?" but you still defo want fascists and communists in the game, then this is the perfect middle ground.

If you played any of the above and thought "Yeesh, not a big fan of how complex they are or how little they teach you about the game in the tutorial," then this is absolutely not the game for you.

If you are looking for a political, societal, or economic simulator but find nothing really scratches the itch, then you may want to consider Vicky II. After you watch some video tutorials, study some of the mechanics (spheres of influence, economics, and trade, to name a few), and play through a trial run or two, you'll finally be able to answer age-old questions such as: "What if the United States became socialist?" "How many territories can I gobble up in Africa without Britain noticing?" and "Can I turn El Salvador into the world power it was always meant to be?"

If you like detail, the game won't disappoint. At any time, you can check census data for your nation, states, or provinces. You can see what ethnic groups work what jobs, what their faith is, and what their standard of living is. You can watch cultural assimilation happen over time. You can influence elections, crush social movements, and interfere with the politics of other nations. For the most part, other nations will play as close to historically as they can manage, but even they are limited by RNG and the butterfly effects of the choices made, so each new game should be different enough.

Well steam wants me to review this so I will. Solid game for those seeking a semi-modern grand strategy game. It starts similar to EU4 with territorial expansion and outright war and ends with modern diplomacy, proxy warring, and stretegic economic moves. Most fans say you play as the "spirit of the nation" similar to EU4. The game has a indeth but limited civilian system where each civilian seeks out the best life for themselves. They seek jobs, socialist and democratic benifits, and have their own income according to their class or job. The limitiations are in how long you actually have to experiance the change of long term civlian benifits since the game is only 100 years long and only the new world gets immigrants. How ever threw the game you change the demographics of your nation from majority poor to majority middle class and the poltical and economic implications of that. The military mechanics are interesting but I never complete a game yet since I am always trying to get the very best start so I only experince the EU4 like mechanics. The game changed from musket line warfare to combined arms with technolgoical advancment. The late game combat is a primitive version of HOI4 and early game is the simlple move stacks to said location in EU4.

This game may be the BEST paradox games for three reasons:
1) It has a comprehensive socio-economic population system that is very complex - so much so that most people who play the game barely understand it.
2) It employs a deep economy system that gives all who attempt to master it a real challenge.
3) It has interesting mechanics: colonization is fun, technology is well-designed, trade is interesting, and overall the military part of the game is rather challenging.

Victoria II, thank you for being a game.

Since humanity will colonize distant star systems before Paradox releases Victoria III it's important not to take what we have for granted. And what we have is some high grade-pure octane Geneva convention ignoring fun. Staring in the 1830s and ending when you fuck up royal, start a war you can't win and inevitably rage quit, Victoria II lets you play as any nation that existed in the early 1830s (Or 1860s if you get the House Divided DLC). Conquer and subjugate the world as a European power, try to modernize for a few decades as an uncivilized nation in Africa or South East Asia before getting raped by the British or the French, or the British or the Spanish or the British or the Portuguese or the British or the Dutch or the British or the Italians or even the British. 

Ban slavery, turn communist, become a republic, become a monarchy, hell if you want homie you can even puppet Haiti for lolz. Do whatever you want.... if you have the power to back it up. 

Pros 
- Full world map
- Every nation playable 
- In depth Technological advancement (go from flint lock muskets to machine guns and Tanks) 
- Africa, Asia and the Middle East is basically free real estate for European empires.

Cons
- Long loading times
- If you expand to fast you'll get punished hard................But we both know you're into that ;)
- Africa, Asia and the Middle East is basically free real estate for European empires.

While the game has a very simplistic, unit commander style, the game doesn't lose excitement, the fact that you can't see battles from a soldiers eyes, makes you sit on the edge of your seat, just waiting to see who wins. And even in a simplistic style of graphics, the politics is still cutthroat, and you sometimes sit there praying that a country will accept your alliance request. Definitely worth every cent.

Clunky, ugly, and outdated, Victoria II is only worth playing if you want to run a grand campaign through the Paradox grand strategy series, and only then because there's no way to convert directly from EU4 to HoI4. The economy is a black box even the developers couldn't comprehend, every system and interface is frustrating and sometimes confusing to use, and on top of that, like all Paradox games it's only even playable if you watch hours of tutorials and gameplay videos. The only thing keeping me playing right now is that I'm getting so close to the end date and conversion to HoI4, and the awful experience of playing this mess may put me off ever doing that again.

I will add that I like that it's not a map painter — I wish CK2 and EU4 were half as good at limiting the player's expansion.

Easily my favourite of the Paradox Strategy games: at least with HPM or a megacampaign conversion, it's feature-complete, less complicated than it looks, and the system is dynamic enough to throw exciting and often amusing consequences up that still can be understood even if you're not totally familiar with the period - what if France lost WWI so badly it fell to a communist coup d'etat, etc? 

I normally play conventional RPGs in a goody-two-shoes manner as it almost always seems the most pragmatically sensible thing to do, but one of the things I love about V2 is that it organically makes you into a complete arsehole, stoking a colonial crisis in order to knock another great power down or sieging out a country just to make sure its economy is so crippled it will never pose a threat again, even once the war has been won. In that way, it's a much more interesting reflection on the terrible morality of the period than either amoral or actively revisionist games set at the same time.

Having bought Victoria II as an inside joke with friends when it was on sale for $5, I decided to give it a try.  I own CK2, EU4, Stellaris and HOi4, all of which I love and have at least 50+ hours on most, this game is my favorite out the bunch, now at the time of this review I've only got ~ 22 hours, however I enjoyed nearly all of those hours, the learning curve surprisingly isn't steep, the game is basic, the Heart of Darkness DLC is a must, and the tutorials are a great help for learning the early stages.  If this is your first Paradox strategy game, you chose a great place to start, if you're a veteran then you should be able to pick it right up and have an abundantly enjoyable experience.  The government, population systems seem overwhelming at first, but as long as you're willing to read short segments you're good to go.  Playing with friends in this game is something that makes it 100x better, solo is fun but with friends, whether working together or VS should be a fun time.  The combat is fun, technological superiority can be felt, mobilization is an amazing feature that is fun to watch as an able-bodied young man joins as an irregular to fight.  Overall this is probably one of a short list of games I would give 10/10 - for reference I gave CK2 10/10, when I review EU4, at this time I would give it 8/10, HOi4 9/10 and Stellaris 6/10.  Looking back 10/10 is a bit high for CK2, however it's still a great game, that's free and I would highly suggest grabbing, however this game is much higher on my list, it's very addicting.  

To conclude, 10/10 game, buy it a full price or on sale, your choice, but it's a worthwhile experience despite the games age.  It feels like a modern game, not a 10 year old game.

An absolute masterpiece. One of my two favorite games of all time. Despite the age, this game is still a must play. I only got it in late 2019 and I still have gotten incredible enjoyment out of it.

Want to make a dominant land-power? You can do that.
Want to play tall and build up an economy, focus on industry, and build a small but modest colonial empire? You can do that too.
Want to become world hegemon and take Britain's crown? You can do that as well.
I absolutely love how this game feels tool, you have to build your country up from the age of Napoleonic warfare to modern ww1 warfare. You have to undergo the industrial revolution and build up your industry, you have to pick where you wanna expand and virtually any part of the map that isn't held by civilized countries is open, you have to pass reforms and slowly liberalize your country unless you want to get an infamous anarcho-liberal revolt, and there are fun mini-challenges you can play with yourself too, like trying to meet all of your pops life needs. T

The game does have flaws though; the economy can be broken at times, there is definitely a meta in terms of where to colonize, blobbing in China in vanilla is broken, liquor factories are absolutely busted in vanilla, and the AI will attack you relentlessly for cores unless you dwarf their military score. Still, a lot of these issues can be softened or negated by playing HPM or another mod. 

Speaking of; the mods are fantastic and just add more flavor and decisions to the game. HPM/HFM just add onto the base game, it's virtually a free expansion pack. There's little to no reason not to download one of the two after your first or second game. I'd recommend them just for the dismantle CB, which makes it so that after a great war you and the victorious powers can divide up your enemies. Although it's recommended that you try to avoid calling minor powers into these or you'll end up with things like Romanian Indochina because the CB doesn't seem to calculate war score in the ensuing negotiation. It's still a greatfeature to the mods though and adds tension; if you lose a great war, everything you worked for and colonized is gone. There are also good Alt-history mods, there's a really sick cold war mod, the concert of europe, etc. etc.

Highly recommend to anyone who likes strategy games and simulators. You need both DLCs, though. Onsale you can get the base game and both DLCs for 20$ (or for 7 rn on humble).

For a 4X game, it's decidedly unhelpful to new players. I feel like more than other games in the genre. But, I mean, if you're looking to get into 4X games or want to try something different than Stellaris or Civ VI (both games I highly recommend), this game is fantastic -- especially for history nerds. I think it's hilarious that in one game in 1910, after a Great War that saw the UK lose and get disarmed, a cabal of commies took over and renamed the UK "The Worker's Commonwealth." Or seeing the U.S. get broken up and a new country called "New England" just keeps eating states from America (first New York, then New Jersey then Pennsylvania, then Ohio). I've had games where Germany failed to get any unification going and Czechoslovakia forms in like 1880 and becomes a massive world power. Sure, it's inaccurate, but you're given an accurate picture of the world in 1836. What you do from there is the fun.

But seriously this game is insanely complicated. Watch a let's play, preferably for the country you're playing as, like in CK 2, there are different plans for each nation, to get an idea on what you should focus on. Check out A Historical Flavour Mod as well. It's the only one I run and I highly recommend it. 

This game is hard. One time I played as Mexico. If you play as Mexico, the U.S. will be like a constant villain for the play through. It's just "Mexico trying to get its literacy rate up" vs. "America wants this, this and this." They're just dicks. Meanwhile, if you're the U.S., you only see yourself trying to become remotely viable against the might that are the European powers. Besides, Mexico is pretty much doomed anyway.

Even if you play as the U.K. and you're brand new, you could still flounder away into bankruptcy by 1838 if you're not watching yourself. 

The UI is not as intuitive as newer games in the genre and you'll definitely go looking for a "Stop General/Admiral Death Pop-Up Spam" mod, but it's just ingenious and kind of amazing to play. Will Japan become terrifying or nah? Will the U.S. avoid the Civil War altogether? Will France ever get its shit together? (Spoiler: only if they're on the winning side of a Great War that sees either Germany or the U.K. put to the guillotine).

This determination was definitely on the fence.

Pros:
Depth - amazingly detailed in terms of the potential of all the information and systems it is using for the price tag you'd be inevitably picking it up for. Rewriting history as someone who grew up with history as their favourite subject in school is always an exciting and interesting experience no matter how many times one replays something. The diversity of playstyles allowed by all of the ideologies coupled together with the fact that there's not really a victory condition so it's just sandbox - means you can set your own goals of winning without the game system telling your otherwise (other than if you are wholly conquered by another nation, ofc).

Con:
It's almost too much detail to handle in a game. I've played hundreds of hours, and I still am trying to figure out how to tame the beast. While it gives you the illusion you can help direct the economy, and as you feel like you should tame it, the games mechanics are subtle and hard to grasp on how it calculates wages (how do you push wages up? you can set it to the highest minimum wage and still there will be workers getting paid £0.1 or whatever, keeping them in poverty and having barely their life needs met, while another worker will get paid £5 and have luxury needs met), fluctuating pricing on goods that result in bankrupt factories that had been performing well before for decades... the list goes on. I'd argue that this game would be perfect and without flaws if only the economy was simplified and (game mechanics) tamed to allow users to either manage the economy as it implies with a 'Planned Economy' ideology, or lightly manage via an interventionist ideology.

Do I like this game? Not exactly.

Is it a bad game? Not at all.

Although I'm not a fan of Vic2, I'm not going leave a bad review. The game isn't deserving of that. It's just not my cup of tea, that's all.

If you came here from HoI4 or EU4 looking for something like those 2 games, you'll be disappointed. Vic2 isn't a diplomacy or military strategy simulator like its contemporaries. Although it contains aspects of those, they aren't the main focus of this game. Vic2 is more of an economy simulator. If EU4 is the guy in the company who does all the frontline PR and marketing and HoI4 is the guy who manages product designs and makes everything work, then Vic2 is the guy who files the company taxes. Compared to other Paradox grand-strategies, Vic2 is nothing special.

That's not to say it's a bad game. It can still be just as fun as the other grand-strategies, it's just that, again, the focus is on the economy and internal politics of your nation rather than on expansion. Too much expansion can actually be detrimental to your nation's stability.

In conclusion, if you like filing taxes while also uniting Germany, you'll like this game.

(P.S. this game is best played in multiplayer clusterfrick matches with friends)

If you like:
- 500 000 militant socialist sieging your capital
- Constant revolts
- Colonialism
- Conscription
- Germany
- Building factories
- Beating Ottomans and China
- Making foreign investments, only to loose all invested money because of nationalization
Then this masterpiece is for you!

Ever feel like you missed out on the scramble for Africa? Have you wanted to send millions of men to die in WWI? Have you ever wanted your nation to crumble under crippling economic sanctions? Then this is the game for you!

In all seriousness Victoria 2 is one of the best paradox games out there. Although it has it's problems, and is dated in many ways, it still holds up as a solid grand strategy game.

Pros:
1. Pops. The Pop system makes this game truly awesome and gives each nation a unique feel. Pops represent your actual population and their statistics determine how your nation functions. For example, a nation such as the UK has high literacy and a well established industrial base, which allows for faster industrialization, whereas a country like Columbia has a relatively low literacy and poorly established industry, which makes the early game about educating and establishing industry, which gives it a much different feel than the UK. It also gives each nation a concrete way to tell how well off a nation is, which differs from games like Hoi4 where each nation has similar levels of development or EU4 which can sometimes feel like just stacking modifiers.
2. Conquest. Both EU4 and HOI4, for as great as they are, feel very much like map painting. Vic2, however, discourages map painting, and instead offers alternative methods such as sphereing, which prevents conflicts over regions from escalating to full scale war at points. Additionally, units take up real pops, so fighting a large war can cost you much of your army, which taps into your real population, aka wars cause you to lose pops which requires you to spend time at peace to recover from wars.
3. Economy. The economy in Vic2 feels realistic and encourages the acquisition of new sources of RGOs, or Resource Gathering Operations. This enourages things like building a large sphere, or in cases of non world powers, specializing your industry to fit the resources available to you. This can make different nations follow different paths of conquest. For example, a nation like the USA has an abundance of RGO to build industry, whereas nations like Japan will have to expand to get what they want, making each nations economic situation unique. Additionally, the fact that goods are sold on an open market makes things like wars have massive effects on world trade.

There are numerous other pros, such as modability.

Cons:
1. UI. The UI feel really dated, and fails to notify you of many things. For example, countries will break alliances, and you can only see that in a little area on your screen, so you often miss important information. Additionally, I feel the game should better notify you of major changes like shifting great power alliances.
2. Rebels. They are crazy. Like I get that you have to keep your population happy, but I should not be having nationwide revolts as a stable nation cause my pops dont have a bit of wool. There are ways to fix this, but it can still be a problem.

However, the pro far outweigh the cons. A couple suggestions however:
1. GET. ALL. DLC. Seriously get all the dlc and the game on sale. You dont need all the unit packs, just Heart of Darkness and House divided. Most mods require both.
2. Start with vanilla, but I recommend switching to HPM soon. HPM is kinda like Vanilla+ and adds a lot more historical content while still keeping it vanilla like.

Overall, great buy!

Pros

Quite possibly one of my favourite games of all time. It's insanely complex, I have no idea how to do anything, but it's so, so satisfying when you manage to do something.

It's different from the other Paradox 4x's, since you don't focus too much on constant conquest (infamy makes sure of that), even though that's still a possibility, but it focuses a lot more on your own realm. What makes it unique, in basic terms, is that it's an economy/industry simulator. Yes, I know it sounds boring, but it isn't. Like I said earlier, it's hard as hell to know what you're doing, but it's the "Wow, I think I've done it!" moments where you realise how that particular thing works in this particular situation that makes this game fun.

Victoria 2 is perhaps the greatest of all Paradox games, though whether it is the best is up for debate. It has taken up the extraordinarily difficult task of simulating an entire global market which, while flawed, is believable enough to make for engaging and captivating gameplay. The endless possibilities of the nations you play will keep you coming back for more, whether it be to achieve continental hegemony as the Austrians, or to rule the waves as Britannia. However, it's age does indeed show. This is most prominent in the UI which, while serviceable, is not nearly as user-friendly as newer games such as EU4. If you can tolerate the substantial learning curve, I believe this is an excellent game for any Paradox fan, when accompanied by the essential DLCs. This game is also helped by a dedicated modding community, with mods such as HPM and HFM taking core mechanics and expanding on them, with mods such as Divergences of Darkness totally changing the setting. In short, this game is much fun, and more captivating than many more modern grand strategy games. I do recommend.

This game is often promoted as "even deeper than Civilization". Bear in mind that mere complexity does not equal sophistication, and neither is a guarantee of fun.

Some players keep a detailed Excel spreadsheet open for reference while playing this game.

I bought this game because i was bored with EU4 and i didn't really expect much. I bought the game without the DLC, and I didn't care for it too much. It was buggy, Prussia was a secondary color, there were no army/navy limits and it was incredibly easy to just build the worlds largest navy and win by default. So I stopped playing for a bit and forgot about the game for about a month, but then I remembered that i never bought the DLC, so I decided to waste more money in attempts to unburden myself from the torture of boredom. 

I didn't buy the DLC, I bought a new game. The game is completely different, the convenience, the new features, and the fact that the game is not historically railroaded along one path. This game has infinite replay value. Want to colonize China as the Ottoman Empire? GO FOR IT! Want to rape Nanjing a few years early? YOU DO YOU! Have a burning desire to murder all of Europe as America? ITS YOUR PARTY, FRIEND! 

FOR NEW BUYERS: Yes this game is very old in the base game. If you do not buy DLC, you will be playing an 8 year old map game. If you do buy the DLC, you will be buying an incredible game that came out in 2020 and has all the newest features. This is not an exaggeration, you need the DLC's. If you don't have the money, that's perfectly fine, they put the game and the DLC on sale all the time. I learned this the hard way as 2 days after I bought the full package, it went on sale for 60% off. 

Overall, the game almost never gets stale, i have yet to get bored with it and when i do eventually get bored, thats what mods are for ;)

Victoria 2 is glorious is every sense of the word. You will find yourself immersed in the dawn of the industrial age, grappling with the tumult and upheaval of development and revolution, while you will also be lifted high by the glory and splendor of the European powers at the height of their power, at the height of their empire, and the height of their resplendence atop the world. Speaking of which, the world is well done, and it is still believably realistic despite its age. While it is not as minutely detailed as CK2 or EUIV, it remains the grandest of them all with a beautiful 19th-century aesthetic. The art itself is a perfect fit, and even dynamic depending on ideology, like is seen in how the heading title of the regular newspaper updates change as a result. There are few strategy games that similarly capture the Victorian aesthetic quite so well. The art only suffers due to its age, which can be seen in  the 3D assets, and while it remains visually engaging this game is in need of an update, or even better, another installment of the series. The sound is good, and the music is a great touch, even if it notably repeats at times. The sound assets themselves are somewhat dated, but still acceptable and satisfying. The gameplay is a shining achievement of grand strategy as a genre, and everything from province development to intricate diplomacy and the deeply complex and as of yet unmatched economic system puts Victoria 2 head and shoulders above other games of a similar type, and even a decade later it blows the mechanics of other games out of the water. Overall, Victoria 2 is amazing, one of my favorite games, and it is in dire need of another installment. For all this, it gets a 9.5/10. Let it be known I will pay whatever Paradox Interactive wants for Victoria 3, and I'll even break my own rule about pre-ordering in order to emphasize my enthusiasm for a prospective Vicky 3. I eagerly await this news with every passing day.

Victoria II, wow, what a game. It may be old, but it certainly still plays fantastically. Play through the 19th century and into the 20th in a game of warfare, diplomacy, industrialisation and colonisation. Play as a great power and place your nation into the spotlight of the world and the annals of history. Play as a middle power and carefully guide your nation towards success. Play as a primitive nation and fend of would-be colonisers.

With the most in-depth economics and industry system of any paradox game and a sophisticated diplomacy system that links perfectly, Victoria II is an excellent representation of the scramble for resources to fuel industrialisation during this era. 

To experience the game fully, the two expansions 'A House Divided' and 'Heart of Darkness' are required. Note, unlike more modern paradox games, these two dlc are all you need for the full experience. For more content and to improve QOL, flavour and performance the HPM (Historical Project Mod) is recommended. Although, if you want even more possibilities, the HFM (Historical Flavour Mod) can alternatively be used.

This game is one of my all-time favourites and even in 2020, nearly a full decade after its release, this game still holds up because of the strength of its fundamental mechanics. This is a game I keep coming back to. I thoroughly enjoy it and hence recommend it to anyone with an interest in industrialisation, colonisation, the time period or just grand-strategy games in general.

Victoria 2 is a grand strategy game starting in the Victorian era, as you guide you nation through the years, you can go to war, conquer, form alliances and great empires. it can be very difficult to play as any nation as you have to carefully have to manage your industry, economy, population, foreign relations and armies. even after 10 years, Victoria 2 holds up well and doesn't appear very dated. there are multiple issues, one of which is the DLC. the DLCs aren't bad by any means, but you absolutely need to have both of them or it'll be a very crappy game. without any DLCs, Victoria 2 is a really bad game. But with DLC, it can be an interesting game if you manage to get a hang of it. playing with others seems to be quite interesting (i'm basing that off of youtube videos because i don't have friends to play with) and can lead to pretty wild things. Sometimes the ai will do something really stupid and you can get an entirely different game every time because of it. overall, it's a pretty good game, and i give it a 7/10

PROS:
+ Gameplay (once you start to understand) is incredibly immersive
+ No harsh limitations on who you can play -- nearly any country can become a "great power" in the hands of an experienced player (except for most countries that get annexed via event)
+ Tutorials don't leave much to be desired; the three different skill levels for tutorial (beginner, intermediate, expert) really help with points of the game you don't understand.
+ The game's mechanics are a welcome addition; in fact, I wish more games had mechanics as rewarding as Vicky 2's. The infamy system, colonization, the feeling of getting no infamy through war justification, westernization, GPs (Great Powers) and SPs (Secondary Powers) -- of course some of these are entirely impossible in other PDX games, but they're still undeniably fun.
+ The game is less heavily focused on military (such as HOI3/4), yet balanced. The balance between the game's aspects in economy, imperialism, population and revolts, military, and so forth make Victoria II one of the most immersive PDX games there is from a roleplaying / diplomatic perspective.
+ The game has no "historical" boundaries -- in all honesty, you can do whatever the hell you want. Want to make the Ottomans a global superpower by 1936? Go for it. Want to challenge yourself to westernize China and take over the east? Do it. Want to make the Confederacy a communist state? Rock on. Want to make Canada a great power, conquer and gain a sphere of influence over America, and become the dominant North American nation? Hell yeah!
+ Mods are varied and incredibly unique -- Divergences is a mod that immediately springs to mind to me. There's also Cold War mods, graphics mods, mods that add more events, accuracies, and flavor to the game, etc. etc.

NEUTRAL:
~ I'm not the hugest fan of DLC. Obviously the game is far better with DLCs. Vicky 2 suffers from the Paradox effect, as I call it -- Paradox games are somewhat barren on release and then get stacked with content in the form of (often) overpriced DLC. There's no American Civil War in base Vicky 2, nor is there an Ottoman collapse event chain. That's in the 2 DLCs -- A House Divided and Heart of Darkness. Please do buy them alongside the base game.
~ This game's learning curve is absolutely insane. I'm nearly 200 hours in and I still struggle to fix my political system, unify Germany, manage my economy, etc. Don't expect to get good at the game in a reasonable amount of time; just like HoI4, you will learn something new about the game every time you play it.
~ Multiplayer can be... frustrating to set up, to say the least. Guides online are usually vague and there's no real good sites to host MP games on. You can go look for Victoria II MP discords, I guess, but good luck. If you want to play with your friends, it'll take an hour or two at least to set up properly.

NEGATIVE:
- You're gonna get struck with bullshit in this game. A lot. That's not to say the design is bad, but sometimes you can just get war randomly declared on you and have no way to fight back. Other times you'll get obliterated during wars where you really should be winning. It just happens; everything in the game happens for one reason or another. It's a learning process.
- Some nations are just objectively not fun to play (*cough cough* Qing *cough cough*). Others are incredibly hard to make GPs. The game is very euro-centric, if you get what I mean (some exceptions, of course, like the USA and Japan).
- The game requires a lot of micromanagement that can easily lose and confuse new players. You'll need a LOT of help with working the trade and economy systems, to name two. The tutorials cover a lot, but not enough to guarantee a decent first game (even as easy countries such as the UK)

That's about as far as I can stretch for negatives.

Should you buy this game? If you like Paradox games or map games in general, absolutely yes.

The last successful Paradox grand strategy game where you can count the DLC on one hand and the one with the least ammount of or at least least important mana as well. 
The Victorian to world wars age was one of innovation, economics and political change that this game captures in a fun and quite detailed way. It is also the only game that I have seen that accounts for the culture, religious belief, literacy and employment status of every household on earth, which feeds into the political uphevils that can ocurr, like the people of the CSA rising up in communist rebelion due to you shutting down the factories, raising tariffs and recinding rights. Not due to each of these actions carrying with it an "+5% revolt risk" modifier, but due to you making a big part of the lower class jobless due to you closing the factories, meaning that they can't get money for their needs and wants, raising the tariffs making many goods more expensive and everyones scant savings being able to buy even less and those imigrants that you alienated with your choice to remove a path to citicenship might become a rallying point for everyone else who has beef with you to also activley fight against you. The economy is also quite detailed and things like being neutral in great wars is a good way to get started on your arms factories for instance. Technology is the most lacking of the three but it is more in-depth than in other games, well actually the research is lacking, the things you get from research are quite suficient albeit unbalanced *Shuders in the enemy having gas attack and you not having gas defence*

Not a perfect game but the best strategy game I have played from Paradox

The most simulator-type game of all the Paradox Development Strategy games, Victoria 2 blends realistic economy and 19th Century diplomacy into a game that I think is a classic. It's old and it hasn't aged well in terms of graphics and interface quality, but this is the game everyone turns too when they want a more modern era type game as its capacity to display modern era diplomacy is uncanny.

Additionally, buy ALL the DLC. This game is unplayable without the DLC but fortunately it has very few compared to CK2 and EU4. There is a mod called HFM which drastically improves the game and many call it an unofficial DLC given how much it improves the game (made by players, not the devs btw).

Also, Victoria III when?
Very steep learning curve but youtube guides are pretty good. Most realistic grand strategy game I've ever played very fun once you get comfortable with it.

I have reassessed my views on this game many times. Lets start with the positives :)
The political system has its moments of "yeah that's cool" when playing. Notably the ability for your people to rebel and make a change in the country. And also the notable world economy, which is quite screwable. While yeah this is exploity, I like the feeling of pulling invisible strings seemingly unrelated and having far reaching impacts. I I also like the constant feeling of Romantacist progress which caries through the game. Meaning advanced nations stomp non-western nations.
Now the bad shit.
The War Mechanics feel like trying to hold water in your hands. As in its total dog shit. I feel like the enemy can constantly slip past my armies because Switzerland keeps giving France military access. And when the Enemy slips past, you effectively have no counter to this. And the entire front collapses. And it devolves into you making a death stack and building forts beforehand to accumulate a totally stupid and arbitrary warscore. And I hate how random events pop up literally every 2 seconds on fast speed. Meaning gameplay is just clicking No, No, No, No, Kill the Child, No War, No, No, Gain Prestige, Random Political Event.

This game is utterly forgotten and neglected by Paradox and left to rot, forgetting about its potential.
Fun Alternate History Experiences possible

It's a reasonably good game. It's fun, it has good replayability, it has intricate mechanics, it feels period-accurate in a way a lot of games (including some Paradox titles) don't, and it doesn't feel like there are any crazy terrible downsides. I recommend it. It's worth playing at least a couple of times.

That said, let's talk downsides. This is a game where sometimes you can't do what you want, and it won't be clear why--for example, who said you couldn't improve your citizens' healthcare? The "upperhouse"? The tutorial didn't really go over that! There are also some truly baffling design choices, like the way the military score is based solely on your generals and navy, and having a big army in itself means nothing at all. You have to do some super gamey things to get ahead--like you have to provoke your populace into being more militant about reform so you can get your upperhouse to actually pass reforms, or how the best way to become a great power is to become a cultural juggernaut, rather than, you know, being a power that is great. It's super unclear what entity you're supposed to represent, since you find yourself going against your elected government, your upper house, and your own citizens all the time. There is also some bad grammar happening, which is surprisingly immersion-breaking.

Honestly, I'd probably rather be playing CK2 or EUIV.

The naval aspect of Victoria II is woefully lacking in an era known for gunboat diplomacy. Critical naval innovations like torpedo boats, destroyers, submarines, early aircraft carriers and steam powered wooden warships are either missing or too abstracted. Victoria 2's predecessor, Victoria: Revolutions had all of these units and in spite of Victoria's II naval simplifications, the AI did not in my games build anything close to a competitive navy. If you had any hopes of a climatic showdown with the Royal Navy in a Jutland style battle, they will be dashed upon the rocks as you watch the AI trivially cross the English Channel.

If you prefer a Pickelhaube to a Pith helmet, you might not care about the naval aspect, but it is a severely lacking part of the game.
